{{Infobox organization |name= Bangladesh Short Film Forum |image= |image_border= |size= |caption= |map= |msize= |mcaption= |motto= |formation= August 1986 |extinction= |type= Organization of independent filmmakers |headquarters= |location= 108, Aziz Super Market, Shahbagh, Dhaka-1000, Bangladesh |membership= |language= [[Bengali language|Bengali]], English |leader_title= President |leader_name= Manzare Hasin Murad |key_people= Anupam Shaikat Shanto (General Secretary), N. Rashed Chowdhury (Vice President), Zahidur Rahim Anjan (Advisor), Tareq Ahmed Bubul (Festival Director) |num_staff= 19 |budget= |website= {{url|www.isiff-bd.org}} }} '''Bangladesh Short Film Forum''' ('''BSFF''') is an organization of young Bangladeshi film makers. It was formed on 24 August 1986 by a group of young independent filmmakers and activists who were then campaigning for creative and aesthetically rich cinema.
Most of these young filmmakers were initiated into cinema through their involvement with the film society movement in Bangladesh that began as early as in the 1960s. Short Film Forum was formed at a time when mainstream Bangladeshi cinema was dominated by crass commercialism and a network of producers-distributors-exhibitors which allowed no space for artistic or socially responsible films.
The Forum featured some of most notable young Bangladeshi film makers among its members, including [[Morshedul Islam]], [[Tanvir Mokammel]], [[Tareque Masud]], Enayet Karim Babul, [[Tareq Shahrier]], [[Shameem Akhter]], [[Manjare Hasin Murad]], Yasmin Kabir, [[Nurul Alam Atique]], Zahidur Rahim Anjan, Rashed Chowdhury, and Akram Khan.<ref>Short Film Festival Newsletter, issue ??, 2007</ref>
Bangladesh Short Film Forum now has its own film center in [[Shahbag]], [[Dhaka]] with an auditorium, a library, an archive and an administrative office.
The Forum is mostly noted for organizing the biennial and non-competitive International Short and Independent Film Festival. The first festival was held in 1988, and was the first festival in the Indian Sub-continent which was entirely dedicated to short films.<ref>{{cite news |title=The year that was... |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/the-year-that-was-57699 |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]] |date=31 December 2014 |accessdate=2015-08-28}}</ref>
The Forum produced a number of short films, including ''One Day in Krishnanagar'' (53 minutes)<ref>{{cite news |title=Daily Star: Documenting Bangladesh |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/magazine/2005/03/03/film.htm |newspaper=The Daily Star}}</ref> and ''Dhaka 2005'' (5 minutes).<ref>[http://www.riff.it/pasteditions/inglese/pasteditions/RIFF06/short/Dhaka%202005.html Dhaka 2005]</ref> It organizes seminars and workshops on films and limited scale film festivals all over Bangladesh, as well as film shows in its Bangladesh Film Center in Shahbag.<ref>{{cite news |title=Meet the Director: Supriyo Sen |url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/entertainment/2015/aug/26/meet-director-supriyo-sen |newspaper=Dhaka Tribune |date=26 August 2015 |accessdate=2015-08-28}}</ref>

Please keep in CREDITS ORDER --> | composer = [[Chris Bacon (composer)|Chris Bacon]] | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 5 | num_episodes = 50 | list_episodes = List of Bates Motel episodes | executive_producer = {{Plainlist| * Mark Wolper * [[Roy Lee]] * [[John Powers Middleton]] * Kerry Ehrin * Carlton Cuse * Vera Farmiga * [[Tucker Gates]] }} | producer = {{Plainlist| * Justis Greene * Steve Kornacki * Alyson Evans * [[Scott Kosar]] * Erica Lipez * Christopher Nelson * [[Tim Southam]] * Jamie Kaye Wheeler }} | location = [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]] | cinematography = {{Plainlist| * [[Thomas Yatsko]] * [[John Bartley|John S. Bartley]] }} | editor = {{Plainlist| * Christopher Nelson * Sarah Boyd * Ryan Neatha Johnson * Vikash Patel * Edward Warschilka }} | runtime = 40–47 minutes | company = {{Plainlist| * American Genre * Carlton Cuse Productions {{small|(2013–2015)}} * Cuse Productions {{small|(2016–2017)}} * Kerry Ehrin Productions * [[Universal Television]] }} | distributor = {{Plainlist| * [[A&E Networks]] * [[NBCUniversal Television Distribution]] }} | network = [[A&E (TV network)|A&E]] | picture_format = [[1080i]] ([[16:9]] [[High-definition television|HDTV]]) | audio_format = [[5.1 surround sound]] | first_aired = {{Start date|2013|3|18}} | last_aired = {{End date|2017|4|24}} | followed_by = | website = http://www.aetv.com/bates-motel | production_website = | open_theme = }}
'''''Bates Motel''''' is an American [[psychological horror]] [[drama (film and television)|drama]] television series that aired from March 18, 2013 to April 24, 2017.<ref>{{cite web |title=A&E Network to Premiere New Original Scripted Drama Series 'Bates Motel' on Monday, March 18 at 10PM ET/PT |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2013/01/04/aande-network-to-premiere-new-original-scripted-drama-series-bates-motel-on-monday-march-18-at-10pm-et-pt-927115/20130104aande02/ |website=The Futon Critic |accessdate=January 4, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title='Psycho' prequel shot in Aldergrove |url=http://www.aldergrovestar.com/news/174861221.html |website=[[Aldergrove Star]] |last=Langmann |first=Kurt |accessdate=January 2, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021225044/http://www.aldergrovestar.com/news/174861221.html |archivedate=October 21, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=BATES MOTEL Set in Aldergrove is Spitting Image of Alfred Hitchcock's Set in Psycho – Updated |url=http://www.yvrshoots.com/2012/11/bates-motel-set-in-aldergrove-just-like-hitchcocks-psycho.html |website=YVR Shoots |accessdate=January 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121127194513/http://yvrshoots.com/2012/11/bates-motel-set-in-aldergrove-just-like-hitchcocks-psycho.html |archivedate=November 27, 2012}}</ref> It was developed by [[Carlton Cuse]], [[Kerry Ehrin]], and [[Anthony Cipriano]], and is produced by [[Universal Television]] and American Genre for the cable network [[A&E (TV network)|A&E]].<ref name="aeorder">{{cite web |title=A&E Network Orders 'Bates Motel' to Series |url=http://www.aetv.com/news/a-e-network-orders-%27bates-motel%27-to-series.-17212020 |website=[[A&E (TV network)|A&E]] |date=July 2, 2012 |accessdate=November 19, 2012 |deadurl= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006043746/http://www.aetv.com/news/a-e-network-orders-%27bates-motel%27-to-series.-17212020 |archivedate=October 6, 2013}}</ref>
The series, a contemporary [[prequel]] to [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s 1960 film ''[[Psycho (1960 film)|Psycho]]''; based on [[Robert Bloch]]'s [[Psycho (novel)|1959 novel of the same name]], depicts the lives of [[Norman Bates]] ([[Freddie Highmore]]) and his mother [[Norma Bates (Psycho)|Norma]] ([[Vera Farmiga]]) prior to the events portrayed in the novel and film, albeit in a different fictional town (White Pine Bay, [[Oregon]], as opposed to Fairvale, [[California]]) and in a modern-day setting.<ref name="latimes">{{cite web|title=Review: 'Bates Motel' a twisty, moody modern prequel to 'Psycho'. |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/mar/18/entertainment/la-et-st-bates-motel-20130318 |website=[[Los Angeles Times]] |last=McNamara |first=Mary |date=March 18, 2013 |accessdate=November 19, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130427060255/http://articles.latimes.com/2013/mar/18/entertainment/la-et-st-bates-motel-20130318 |archivedate=April 27, 2013}}</ref><ref name="starpulse">{{cite web|title='Bates Motel': An Intriguing Contemporary Prequel To 'Psycho' |url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/Alan_Danzis/2013/03/18/bates_motel_review_an_intriguing_conte |website=Starpulse |first=Alan |last=Danzis |date=March 18, 2013 |accessdate=April 16, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130322072731/http://www.starpulse.com/news/Alan_Danzis/2013/03/18/bates_motel_review_an_intriguing_conte |archivedate=March 22, 2013}}</ref> However, the final season loosely adapts the plot of ''Psycho''. [[Max Thieriot]] and [[Olivia Cooke]] both starred as part of the main cast throughout the series' run. After recurring in the first season, [[Nestor Carbonell]] was added to the main cast from season two onward.
The series begins in Arizona with the death of Norma's husband, after which Norma purchases the Seafairer motel located in a coastal Oregon town so that she and Norman can start a new life.<ref name="aeorder"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Mother, as She Lives and Breathes |url=http://tv.nytimes.com/2013/03/18/arts/television/bates-motel-with-vera-farmiga-on-ae.html |website=[[The New York Times]] |last=Stanley |first=Alessandra |date=March 17, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130624220548/http://tv.nytimes.com/2013/03/18/arts/television/bates-motel-with-vera-farmiga-on-ae.html |archivedate=June 24, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Tension builds in The Lake, but dies at the Bates Motel |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2013/03/17/3291295/tension-builds-in-the-lake-but.html |website=[[Miami Herald]] |last=Garvin |first=Glenn |date=March 17, 2013 |deadurl= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021070700/http://www.miamiherald.com/2013/03/17/3291295/tension-builds-in-the-lake-but.html |archivedate=October 21, 2013}}</ref> Subsequent seasons follow Norman as his mental illness becomes dangerous, and Norma as she struggles to protect her son, and those around him, from himself. The series was filmed outside [[Greater Vancouver|Vancouver]] in [[Aldergrove, British Columbia]], along with other locations within the [[Fraser Valley]] of British Columbia.
[[A&E (TV channel)|A&E]] chose to skip a pilot of the series, opting to go straight-to-series by ordering a 10-episode first season.<ref name="aeorder"/> On June 15, 2015, the series was renewed for a fourth and fifth season, making ''Bates Motel'' A&E's longest-running original scripted drama series in the channel's history.<ref>{{cite web|title='Bates Motel' Renewed for Two More Seasons at A&E; 'Returned' Cancelled |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/bates-motel-renewed-returned-canceled-801653 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |last=Goldberg |first=Lesley |date=June 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150617162553/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/bates-motel-renewed-returned-canceled-801653 |archivedate=June 17, 2015}}</ref> The series' lead actors, Vera Farmiga and Freddie Highmore, received particular praise for their performances in the series, with the former receiving a [[Primetime Emmy Award]] nomination and winning a [[Saturn Award for Best Actress on Television]]. ''Bates Motel'' also won three [[People's Choice Awards]] for Favorite Cable TV Drama, and for Favorite Cable TV Actress (Farmiga) and Actor (Highmore).
==Series overview== {{main|List of Bates Motel episodes}} {{:List of Bates Motel episodes}}<!--To edit this table, go to the List of episodes page-->
===Season 1=== {{Main|Bates Motel (season 1)}} The first season follows Norma and Norman Bates as they buy a motel after Norman's father dies. On one of the first nights of the two owning the motel, the former owner breaks in and sexually assaults Norma. Norman knocks the attacker out, and Norma stabs him to death. She decides it's best not to call the police and to cover up the murder. She and Norman dispose of the body. He complicates the cover-up by keeping a belt that belonged to the victim. When the town sheriff and his deputy notice that a man has gone missing, Norma and Norman must keep them from digging too far.
===Season 2=== {{Main|Bates Motel (season 2)}} The second season follows the aftermath of Norman's teacher's murder, as her mysterious past comes to light. Meanwhile, Norma finds herself making dangerous decisions in order to keep the motel running and preventing the impending bypass. Bradley's search for her father's killer leads to the extremes, and Dylan learns the disturbing truth about his parentage.
===Season 3=== {{Main|Bates Motel (season 3)}} The third season focuses on Norman's waning deniability about what's happening to him, and the lengths he will go to gain control of his fragile psyche. The dramatic events of last season leave Norma more aware of her son's mental fragility and fearful of what he is capable of. Meanwhile, Sheriff Romero begins to distance himself from the Bates family after he suspects Norma is lying to him about her husband's death.
===Season 4=== {{Main|Bates Motel (season 4)}} The fourth season follows Norma as she becomes increasingly fearful of Norman, going to great lengths to find him the professional help he needs. This complicates their once unbreakable trust as Norman struggles to maintain his grip on reality. Meanwhile, Sheriff Romero once again finds himself drawn into Norma and Norman's lives. He agrees to marry Norma because his insurance will enable her to place Norman in an expensive psychiatric hospital. His generosity backfires, however, when Norman learns of the marriage. Norman bitterly resents Romero for coming between him and his mother and at one point threatens the sheriff with an axe.
===Season 5=== {{Main|Bates Motel (season 5)}} The fifth season begins two years after the death of Norma. Publicly happy and well-adjusted, Norman struggles at home, where his blackouts are increasing and "Mother" threatens to take him over completely. Meanwhile, Dylan and Emma find themselves drawn back into Norman's world, and Romero hungers for revenge against his stepson, Norman.
==Cast and characters== {{main|List of Bates Motel characters}} * [[Vera Farmiga]] as [[Norma Bates (Psycho)|Norma Louise Bates]] * [[Freddie Highmore]] as [[Norman Bates]] * [[Max Thieriot]] as Dylan Massett * [[Olivia Cooke]] as Emma Decody * [[Nicola Peltz]] as Bradley Martin (main season 1; recurring seasons 2–3) * [[Nestor Carbonell]] as Sheriff Alex Romero (recurring season 1; main seasons 2–5) * [[Kenny Johnson]] as Caleb Calhoun (recurring seasons 2 and 5; main season 3; guest season 4)
==Production==
===Development=== [[File:Bates Motel Cast 2013.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The cast promoting the series at the [[Paley Center for Media]], 2013 (left to right) Thieriot, Peltz, Highmore, Farmiga, and Carbonell]] On January 12, 2012, it was reported that A&E were developing a television series titled ''Bates Motel'' that would serve as a prequel to the [[Alfred Hitchcock]] film ''[[Psycho (1960 film)|Psycho]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/tca-psycho-prequel-series-bates-281527 |title=TCA: 'Psycho' Prequel Series 'Bates Motel' in the Works at A&E |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |last=Goldberg |first=Lesley |date=January 12, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150519212915/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/tca-psycho-prequel-series-bates-281527 |archivedate=May 19, 2015}}</ref> The first script was written by [[Anthony Cipriano]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2012/01/13/ae-bates-motel-those-who-kill |title=A&E developing 'Psycho' prequel TV series |website=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |last=Semigran |first=Aly |date=January 12, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403135545/http://www.ew.com/article/2012/01/13/ae-bates-motel-those-who-kill |archivedate=April 3, 2015}}</ref> In March 2012, [[Carlton Cuse]] and [[Kerry Ehrin]] joined the project as executive producers and head writers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/03/10/lost-showrunner-carlton-cuse-joins-psycho-prequel |title=Lost Showrunner Carlton Cuse Joins Psycho Prequel |website=[[IGN]] |last=Goldman |first=Eric |date=March 9, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160508223304/http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/03/10/lost-showrunner-carlton-cuse-joins-psycho-prequel |archivedate=May 8, 2016}}</ref> Cuse has cited the drama series ''[[Twin Peaks]]'' as a key inspiration for ''Bates Motel'', stating, "We pretty much ripped off ''Twin Peaks''... If you wanted to get that confession, the answer is yes. I loved that show. They only did 30 episodes. Kerry [Ehrin] and I thought we'd do the 70 that are missing."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2013/05/carlton-cuse-at-bates-motel-panel-we-pretty-much-ripped-off-twin-peaks/ |title=Carlton Cuse At 'Bates Motel' Panel: "We Pretty Much Ripped Off 'Twin Peaks'" |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |last=Haithman |first=Diane |date=May 10, 2013 |accessdate=May 11, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130607065706/http://www.deadline.com/2013/05/carlton-cuse-at-bates-motel-panel-we-pretty-much-ripped-off-twin-peaks/ |archivedate=June 7, 2013}}</ref> On July 2, 2012, A&E gave ''Bates Motel'' a straight-to-series order.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/ae-bates-motel-psycho-prequel-lost-carlton-cuse-344144/ |title=A&E Orders Carlton Cuse's 'Psycho' Prequel 'Bates Motel' Straight to Series |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |last=Goldberg |first=Lesley |date=July 2, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426095730/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/ae-bates-motel-psycho-prequel-lost-carlton-cuse-344144 |archivedate=April 26, 2014}}</ref> [[Chris Bacon (composer)|Chris Bacon]] was hired to score the music for the series in January 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2013/01/12/chris-bacon-to-score-bates-motel/ |title=Chris Bacon to Score 'Bates Motel' |website=Film Music Reporter |date=January 12, 2013}}</ref>
===Casting=== On August 27, 2012, [[Vera Farmiga]] was the first to be cast in the leading role of Norma Louise Bates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2012/08/27/norma-bates-psycho-series/ |title=Norman Bates' mother cast in A&E's 'Psycho' series |website=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |last=Hibberd |first=James |date=August 27, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140820115110/http://insidetv.ew.com/2012/08/27/norma-bates-psycho-series/ |archivedate=August 20, 2014 }}</ref> On September 14, 2012, [[Freddie Highmore]] was cast as Norman Bates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/bates-motel-freddie-highmore-1053089.aspx |title=Keck's Exclusives: Bates Motel Casts Its Norman – Today's News: Our Take |website=[[TV Guide]] |last=Keck |first=William |date=September 14, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018085749/http://www.tvguide.com/news/bates-motel-freddie-highmore-1053089.aspx |archivedate=October 18, 2014}}</ref> That same day, [[Max Thieriot]] was cast as Norman's half-brother, Dylan Massett.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/ae-bates-motel-psycho-prequel-max-thieriot-freddie-highmore-vera-farmiga-370533 |title=A&E's 'Bates Motel' Adds Max Thieriot as Norman's Brother |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |last=Goldberg |first=Lesley |date=September 14, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141127121857/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/ae-bates-motel-psycho-prequel-max-thieriot-freddie-highmore-vera-farmiga-370533 |archivedate=November 27, 2014}}</ref> Shortly after, on September 19, 2012, [[Nicola Peltz]] was cast as Bradley Martin, a possible love interest for Norman.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/bates-motel-psycho-prequel-cast-ae-nicola-peltz-371440 |title='Bates Motel' Adds 'Last Airbender' Actress as Love Interest for Norman (Exclusive) |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |last=Goldberg |first=Lesley |date=September 19, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141127122128/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/bates-motel-psycho-prequel-cast-ae-nicola-peltz-371440 |archivedate=November 27, 2014}}</ref> Finally, on September 20, 2012, [[Olivia Cooke]] was the final main cast member to join the series, in the role of Emma Decody, Norman's best friend.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/news/a407099/psycho-tv-prequel-bates-motel-adds-blackout-star-olivia-cooke.html |title='Psycho' TV prequel 'Bates Motel' adds 'Blackout' star Olivia Cooke |website=[[Digital Spy]] |last=Jeffery |first=Morgan |date=September 20, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029201340/http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/news/a407099/psycho-tv-prequel-bates-motel-adds-blackout-star-olivia-cooke.html |archivedate=October 29, 2013}}</ref> [[Nestor Carbonell]] was cast in a recurring role as Sheriff Alex Romero in the first season, but was upgraded to the main cast at the beginning of the second season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2012/10/mike-vogel-nestor-carbonell-join-aes-bates-motel-trio-to-recur-on-shameless-346722/ |title=Mike Vogel & Nestor Carbonell Join A&E's 'Bates Motel', Trio To Recur On 'Shameless' |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |date=October 2, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160611155440/http://deadline.com/2012/10/mike-vogel-nestor-carbonell-join-aes-bates-motel-trio-to-recur-on-shameless-346722/ |archivedate=June 11, 2016}}</ref> In July 2014, [[Kenny Johnson]], who recurred as Norma's brother Caleb Calhoun in the second season, was promoted to a series regular for the third season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spoilertv.com/2014/07/bates-motel-season-3-kenny-johnson.html |title=Bates Motel – Season 3 – Kenny Johnson upped to Regular |website=SpoilerTV |accessdate=February 23, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224012618/http://www.spoilertv.com/2014/07/bates-motel-season-3-kenny-johnson.html |archivedate=February 24, 2015}}</ref> It was announced on July 22, 2016 at [[San Diego Comic-Con International]] that [[Rihanna]] would appear in the iconic role of [[Marion Crane]] for the fifth and final season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Comic-Con: 'Bates Motel' Taps Rihanna for Famous 'Psycho' Role |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/bates-motel-rihanna-set-psycho-912166 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |last=Goldberg |first=Lesley |date=July 22, 2016 |accessdate=July 24, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160724160017/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/bates-motel-rihanna-set-psycho-912166 |archivedate=July 24, 2016}}</ref>
===Filming=== A replica of the original Bates Motel set from the film ''Psycho'' was built on location at approximately 1054 272nd Street in [[Aldergrove, British Columbia]], where portions of the series were filmed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/movies/index.ssf/2013/03/bates_motel_whats_going_on_in.html |title='Bates Motel': What's going on in that bucolic Oregon coastal town |website=[[OregonLive.com]] |first=Kristi |last=Turnquist |date=March 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928121613/http://www.oregonlive.com/movies/index.ssf/2013/03/bates_motel_whats_going_on_in.html |archivedate=September 28, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yvrshoots.com/2012/11/bates-motel-set-in-aldergrove-just-like-hitchcocks-psycho.html |title=BATES MOTEL Set in Aldergrove is Spitting Image of Alfred Hitchcock's Set in Psycho – Updated |website=YVR Shoots |first=Susan |last=Gittins |date=November 15, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121127194513/http://yvrshoots.com/2012/11/bates-motel-set-in-aldergrove-just-like-hitchcocks-psycho.html |archivedate=November 27, 2012}}</ref> The original house and motel is located in [[Universal Studios]], [[Hollywood]], [[Los Angeles]]. Additional filming for the series took place in multiple areas in [[Metro Vancouver]], including [[Steveston, British Columbia|Steveston]], [[Coquitlam]], [[Horseshoe Bay, West Vancouver]] and [[Fort Langley]]. In February 2017, after filming was completed for the series, the Bates Motel exterior set in Aldergrove was demolished.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vancouversun.com/entertainment/television/bates-motel-torn-down |title=Hollywood North: The Bates Motel gets hit by the wrecking ball (gallery) |website=[[The Vancouver Sun]] |first=Scott |last=Brown |date=February 4, 2017 |accessdate=February 23, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223211824/http://vancouversun.com/entertainment/television/bates-motel-torn-down |archivedate=February 23, 2017}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Critical response=== The first season of ''Bates Motel'' received a score of 66 on [[Metacritic]], indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/bates-motel/critic-reviews |title=Bates Motel: Season 1 Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |date=March 18, 2013 |accessdate=March 22, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130322045752/http://www.metacritic.com/tv/bates-motel/critic-reviews |archivedate=March 22, 2013}}</ref> Review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reported that 81% of 37 critics gave the first season a positive review. The site's consensus reads, "''Bates Motel'' utilizes mind manipulation and suspenseful fear tactics, on top of consistently sharp character work and wonderfully uncomfortable familial relationships."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/bates-motel/s01/ |title=Bates Motel: Season 1 (2013) |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=October 10, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307132607/http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/bates-motel/s01/ |archivedate=March 7, 2014}}</ref> The second season of ''Bates Motel'' received a score of 67 out of 100 on Metacritic, from 11 reviews, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/bates-motel/season-2 |title=Bates Motel: Season 2 Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=March 15, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140314132737/http://www.metacritic.com/tv/bates-motel/season-2 |archivedate=March 14, 2014}}</ref> Rotten Tomatoes reported an 86% rating from 12 reviews for the second season. The site's consensus reads, "''Bates Motel'' reinvents a classic thriller with believable performances and distinguished writing."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/bates-motel/s02/ |title=Bates Motel: Season 2 (2014) |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=March 15, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006222509/http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/bates-motel/s02 |archivedate=October 6, 2014}}</ref>
The third season of ''Bates Motel'' received a score of 72 out of 100 on Metacritic, from 5 reviews, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/bates-motel/season-3 |title=Bates Motel: Season 3 Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=March 10, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150309215043/http://www.metacritic.com/tv/bates-motel/season-3 |archivedate=March 9, 2015}}</ref> Rotten Tomatoes reported a 92% rating from 12 reviews. The site's consensus reads, "''Bates Motel'' further blurs lines around TV's creepiest taboo mother/son relationship, uncomfortably darkening its already fascinating tone."<ref name="Reviews">{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/bates-motel/s03/ |title=Bates Motel: Season 3 (2015) |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=March 10, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150310003936/http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/bates-motel/s03/ |archivedate=March 10, 2015}}</ref> The fourth season of ''Bates Motel'' was met with positive reviews from critics. Rotten Tomatoes reported a 100% positive rating from 8 reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/bates-motel/s04/ |title=Bates Motel: Season 4 (2016) |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=March 11, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160327233412/http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/bates-motel/s04/ |archivedate=March 27, 2016}}</ref> The fifth and final season of ''Bates Motel'' received a score of 81 out of 100 on Metacritic, from 8 reviews, indicating "universal acclaim".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/bates-motel/season-5 |title=Bates Motel: Season 5 Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=February 25, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223080935/http://www.metacritic.com/tv/bates-motel/season-5 |archivedate=February 23, 2017}}</ref> Rotten Tomatoes reported a 100% rating from 8 reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/bates-motel/s05/ |title=Bates Motel: Season 5 (2017) |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=March 15, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150901081300/http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/bates-motel/s05 |archivedate=September 1, 2015}}</ref>

==International broadcast== In Canada, the series airs only on the U.S. network A&E, which is available through most Canadian cable and satellite companies. In Australia, the series premiered on [[Fox8]] on May 26, 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxtel.com.au/whats-on/foxtel-insider/fox8-secures-highly-anticipated-bates-motel-211521.htm |title=FOX8 Secures Highly Anticipated "Bates Motel" |website=Foxtel.com |date=March 20, 2013 |accessdate=April 28, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130405105952/http://www.foxtel.com.au/whats-on/foxtel-insider/fox8-secures-highly-anticipated-bates-motel-211521.htm |archivedate=April 5, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In the UK and Ireland, it premiered on [[Universal Channel (UK and Ireland)|Universal Channel]] on April 2, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvwise.co.uk/2013/08/universal-channel-sets-uk-premiere-date-for-bates-motel/ |title=Universal Channel Sets UK Premiere Date For 'Bates Motel' |website=TVWise |date=August 9, 2013 |accessdate=August 23, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130816043246/http://www.tvwise.co.uk/2013/08/universal-channel-sets-uk-premiere-date-for-bates-motel/ |archivedate=August 16, 2013}}</ref> In Jamaica, it premiered on [[CVM Television|CVM TV]] on August 11, 2014. In the Middle East, it premiered on [[OSN|OSN First HD]] in mid-2014. The second season premiered on January 5, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.osn.com/onlineguide/january/ |title=January 2015 Programming Highlights |website=OSN.com |accessdate=January 11, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150114225423/http://www.osn.com/onlineguide/january/ |archivedate=January 14, 2015}}</ref> In the Philippines, ''Bates Motel'' began airing on [[Jack TV]] on August 12, 2013. In South Africa, the series premiered on [[MNet]] on June 21, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mnet.dstv.com/2013/08/09/bates-motel-fri-at-2130-3/ |title=Bates Motel: Fri at 21:30 |website=MNet |date=August 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202221459/http://mnet.dstv.com/2013/08/09/bates-motel-fri-at-2130-3/ |archivedate=December 2, 2013}}</ref> The series premiered in India on [[Colors Infinity]] on November 6, 2015.
==Merchandising== [[NBCUniversal]] partnered with [[Hot Topic]], the American [[Retailing|retailer]] of pop culture merchandise, to introduce a collection of clothing and accessories inspired by ''Bates Motel''. The merchandise, including items such as bathrobes and bloody shower curtains, became available at Hot Topic's website and select stores on March 18, 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2014/03/18/nbcuniversal-television-consumer-products-and-retailer-hot-topic-introduce-new-product-line-inspired-by-the-aande-hit-original-series-bates-motel-651313/20140318nbc04/ |title=NBCUniversal Television Consumer Products and Retailer Hot Topic Introduce New Product Line Inspired by the A&E Hit Original Series 'Bates Motel' |website=The Futon Critic |date=March 18, 2014 |accessdate=March 27, 2014}}</ref> As of 2018, the merchandise is no longer available through Hot Topic.

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox magazine | image_file = | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = Annemette Krakau | editor_title = Editor-in-chief | frequency = Weekly | circulation = 150,000 (2013) | category = Celebrity magazine
Entertainment magazine
TV magazine
[[Women's magazine]] | company = [[Aller Media]] | publisher = Aller Press AS | firstdate = {{start date and age|df=y|1938|4|5}} | finaldate = | country = [[Denmark]] | based = [[Copenhagen]] | language = [[Danish language|Danish]] | website = [http://www.billedbladet.dk/ ''Billed Bladet''] | issn = | oclc = }} '''''Billed Bladet''''' is a [[Danish language]] weekly entertainment and royal magazine published in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. Being founded in 1938 it is one of the oldest magazines in the country. ==History and profile== ''Billed Bladet'' was first published on 5 April 1938.{{cite news|author1=Birgitte Rahbek|author2=Thorkil Jacobsen|title=75 års danmarkshistorie i billeder|url=http://www.b.dk/kultur/75-aars-danmarkshistorie-i-billeder|accessdate=27 February 2015|work=Berlingske|date=4 April 2013|language=Danish}}{{cite book|title=Europa World Year|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wGA4o-UhAfgC&pg=PA1439|accessdate=8 March 2015|year=2004|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-85743-254-1|page=1439}} The magazine was modelled on the American magazines ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' and ''[[Look (American magazine)|Look]]''. ''Billed Bladet'' is part of [[Aller Media]].{{cite web|title=Billed-bladet.dk|url=http://www.publicitas.com/en/home/media-solutions/media-search/media-factsheet-detail/?PARAM1=AV1BV4#.VPCJXLOsXRA|work=Publicitas|accessdate=27 February 2015}} The former owner of the magazine was Den Berlingske Gruppe.{{cite web|title=Carl Allers Etablissement A/S|url=http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history/Ca-Ch/Carl-Allers-Etablissement-A-S.html|work=Reference for Business|accessdate=23 March 2015}} Aller Media acquired the magazine in 1987. It is published by Aller Press AS weekly{{cite web|author1=Mike Friedrichsen|author2=Astrid Kurad|title=The Magazine Market in Denmark and Germany|url=http://citation.allacademic.com/meta/p_mla_apa_research_citation/1/7/1/5/9/pages171593/p171593-14.php|work=All Academic|accessdate=28 February 2015|format=Conference Paper|date=23 May 2007}} and has its headquarters in Copenhagen.{{cite web|title=Billed-Bladet|url=http://www.publicitas.com/en/home/media-solutions/media-search/advanced-media-search/media-factsheet-detail/mediadata/billed-bladet/?PARAM1=AV1BV3#.VPCKMLOsXRA|work=Publicitas|accessdate=27 February 2015}}{{cite book|title=The Europa World Year Book 2003|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XLvU9lroRuUC&pg=PA1403|accessdate=10 March 2015|date=10 July 2003|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-85743-227-5|page=1404}} During its early period ''Billed Bladet'' had a much more comprehensive coverage and included more photographs.{{cite journal|author=Sune Bechmann|title="Now we should all acknowledge our holocaust guilt."|journal=CFE Working paper series|date=2008|issue=37|url=http://lup.lub.lu.se/luur/download?func=downloadFile&recordOId=2223427&fileOId=2223428|accessdate=7 May 2015}} Immediately after [[World War II]] the magazine published the photographs of the [[Nazi concentration camps]] in [[Germany]]. Later it began to provide news on [[celebrities]]{{cite book|author=Nicolai Graakjaer|title=Analyzing Music in Advertising: Television Commercials and Consumer Choice|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NlOcBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA121|accessdate=27 February 2015|date=27 November 2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-67190-9|page=121}}{{cite journal|author=Kirsten Sparre|title=Shared Emotions and a Forum for Gossiping|journal=Nordicom|url=http://www.nordicom.gu.se/sites/default/files/kapitel-pdf/26_063-070.pdf|accessdate=27 February 2015}} and [[royal families]] as well as on [[television programs]], including Vild med dans (Denmark’s [[Dancing with the Stars]]) and X-factor (Denmark’s Got Talent).{{cite web|title=Billed Bladet|url=http://www.aller.dk/wp-content/uploads/BILLED-BLADET1.pdf|work=Aller Media|accessdate=27 February 2015}}{{cite web|title=Entertainment |url=http://www.affinity-primemedia.ch/newsonline_images/1114/aller.pdf |work=Affinity Primemedia |accessdate=21 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518094014/http://www.affinity-primemedia.ch/newsonline_images/1114/aller.pdf |archivedate=18 May 2015 |df=dmy }} The weekly publishes a list of Dress of the Week. Its target audience is women over forty. ''Billed Bladet'' has high [[ethical standards]] in regard to the news it publishes. For a long time the magazine asked the permission of the members of the [[Royal family of denmark|Danish royal family]] when they would be photographed in public places. Later this policy was changed and they began to be photographed based on the decision of the editorial team of the magazine. Annemette Krakau has been the [[editor-in-chief]] of ''Billed Bladet'' since 2006. ==Circulation== ''Billed Bladet'' had a circulation of 146,450 copies in 1956, 127,257 copies in 1960 and 140,065 copies in 1964.{{cite web|author=Aage Erhardtsen|title=Evolution of concentration and competition in the Danish newspaper and magazine sector|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Evolution_of_concentration_and_competiti.html?id=rCc-AAAAMAAJ&redir_esc=y|work=Commission of the European Communities|accessdate=29 May 2016|location=Brussels|format=Report|date=May 1978}} It rose to 241,757 copies in 1970 and to 373,650 copies in 1974. The magazine sold 183,000 copies in 2001{{cite web|title=Statistical Yearbook 2002|url=http://www.dst.dk/Site/Dst/Udgivelser/GetPubFile.aspx?id=18500&sid=entire2002|work=Denmarks Statistik|accessdate=9 May 2016|page=157}} and 185,000 copies in 2003.{{cite web|title=The Magazine Market in Denmark and Germany|url=http://citation.allacademic.com/meta/p_mla_apa_research_citation/1/7/1/5/9/pages171593/p171593-14.php|work=All Academic Research|accessdate=5 April 2015}} The magazine had a circulation of 204,700 copies in 2006,{{cite web|title=Top ten titles by circulation/issue 2006|url=http://www.nordicom.gu.se/sites/default/files/medieforskning-statistik/1131_2030_Cons_mags_top10_2006.xls|work=Nordicom|accessdate=28 February 2015}} 201,000 copies in 2007 and 195,000 copies in 2008.{{cite web|title=Statistical Yearbook 2009|url=http://circumpolarhealth.org/library/DK-Statistical-Yearbook-2009.pdf|work=Statistics Denmark|accessdate=5 April 2015|date=June 2009}} The circulation of the magazine was 176,786 copies in 2010 and 163,869 copies in 2011.{{cite web|title=Top 50 Magazines|url=http://ifabc.org/site/assets/media/Top-50-magazines-30042014.xlsx|work=IFABC|accessdate=22 March 2015|date=30 April 2014}} It was 150,263 copies in 2012. The weekly had a circulation of 150,000 copies both in the second half of 2013 and in 2013 as a whole.{{cite web|title=Consumer-paid magazines by circulation|url=http://www.statbank.dk/statbank5a/default.asp?w=1280|work=StatBank Denmark|accessdate=28 February 2015}} ==See also== * [[List of magazines in Denmark]] ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== * [http://www.billedbladet.dk/ Official website] [[Category:1938 establishments in Denmark]] [[Category:Danish-language magazines]] [[Category:Danish weekly magazines]] [[Category:Danish women's magazines]] [[Category:Entertainment magazines]] [[Category:Listings magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1938]] [[Category:Media in Copenhagen]] [[Category:Television magazines]]

page.title: Billy Connolly's World Tour of England, Ireland and Wales

revision.comment: This episode guide is horrific - there's not one sentence that makes sense. This was added by an anonymous editor a year ago. I'm restoring the previous version, which had less detail, but was readable. If someone wants to re-add some of the locales visited, that would be fine - I have no objection to the content, just the absolute lack of grammar and clarity.
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox television| |show_name = Billy Connolly's World Tour of England, Ireland and Wales |image = Billy Connolly WToEIW.jpg |caption = DVD box-set cover |runtime = 200 minutes
(25 min/episode) |creator = [[Billy Connolly]]
Nobby Clark
Steve Brown |starring = Billy Connolly |country = United Kingdom |network = [[BBC One]] |first_aired = 2002 |last_aired = |num_episodes = 8 }} '''''Billy Connolly's World Tour of England, Ireland and Wales''''' is the third of Scottish comedian [[Billy Connolly]]'s "world tours" commissioned by the [[BBC]]. It was first aired in 2002, and was released on DVD in 2004, with three episodes on disc one and the remaining five on disc two. ==Episode guide== '''Episode 1:''' In the first episode, Connolly visits the city of [[Dublin]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] '''Episode 2:''' Connolly visits the city of [[Belfast]] in [[Northern Ireland]]. While there, he visits a graveyard that has a wall built under the ground to keep the [[Protestants]] and [[Catholics]] apart in death. '''Episode 3:''' While still in Ireland, Connolly visits the town of [[Killarney]] and surrounding areas. '''Episode 4:''' Connolly's first episode to be set in England starts in the city of [[Newcastle upon Tyne]]. On his visit he gives an insight to how the [[Geordie]]s got their nickname. '''Episode 5:''' The fifth episode focuses on the nation's capital, [[London]]. Connolly climbs to the top of the [[Big Ben]] clock tower, rides down the [[River Thames]], and performs at [[Shakespeare's Globe]]. '''Episode 6:''' Connolly visits the cities of [[Manchester]] and [[Sheffield]]. '''Episode 7:''' The whole episode focuses on the country of Wales, in which he visits [[Cardiff]], the [[Brecon Beacons]] and [[Portmeirion]]. '''Episode 8:''' In the final episode of the series, Connolly visits [[Bournemouth]]. In an almost traditional way for his World Tour Series, he strips down to nothing as he rides off on his bike during the ending credits. ==Music== The closing credits of each episode feature [[Ralph McTell]], [[Cara Dillon]] and [[Mary Hopkin]] singing verses of McTell's song, "England" (suitably adapted for 'Ireland' and 'Cymru'). Hopkin can additionally be heard singing a verse of "[[Bugeilio'r Gwenith Gwyn]]" during Episode 7. The DVD also includes audio tracks of songs performed by Connolly and Dillon, and instrumental versions of three McTell compositions (including the series' theme tune). == External links == * {{IMDb title|0312484|Billy Connolly's World Tour of England, Ireland and Wales}} {{Billy Connolly}} [[Category:2002 British television programme debuts]] [[Category:2002 British television programme endings]] [[Category:2000s British television series]] [[Category:Scottish television programmes]] [[Category:BBC television documentaries]] [[Category:Comedy tours]] [[Category:Billy Connolly]] [[Category:English-language television programs]]

The '''Brunei Cup''' is an annual [[basketball]] tournament held at [[Brunei]]. Originally held in 2001, with most of the teams coming from [[Overseas Filipino]] workers in Brunei, the tournament has since expanded to include several professional and national teams around [[Asia]] and [[Australia]].
==2008 Team profile== Darwin Airport Resort All-Stars *Head Coach : Don Sheppard
The games are held at Brunei's National Indoor Stadium.

page.title: Centre National du Costume de Scene

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
{{Infobox museum | name = Centre National du Costume de Scene
(The National Center of Costume and Scenography) | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = CNCS - Moulins.JPG | imagesize = 200 | caption = | alt = | map_type = | map_relief = | map_size = | map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|46|33|40.83|N|3|19|7.13|E|display=inline,title}} | established = 2006 | dissolved = | location = Quartier Villars, Route de Montilly, Moulins, France | type = | accreditation = | key_holdings = | collections = Costumes, scenery, paintings | collection_size = | visitors = | director = | president = | curator = | owner = | publictransit = | car_park = | network = | website = {{URL|http://www.cncs.fr}} }} {{Costume}} '''Centre National du Costume de Scene''' (CNCS) ([[English language|English]]: '''The National Center of Costume and Scenography''' (CNCS)), is a French museum dedicated to stage costumes and sets. It was inaugurated on 1 July 2006 in [[Moulins, Allier]] by [[Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres]] the [[Minister of Culture (France)|Minister of Culture]], [[Pierre-André Périssol]] the mayor of [[Moulins, Allier|Moulins]] and [[Christian Lacroix]], dressmaker and board chairman.{{cite web | url=http://www.cnac.fr/media/documents/2013_07_CNCS_Expo_costumes_brochure.pdf | title=Centre National du Costume de Scene | publisher=CNAC | accessdate=16 December 2013 | pages=4}} The current director is Delphine Pinasa, whose portrait is exhibited at the museum. ==History== It is located in the old district of [[Moulins, Allier|Moulins]], [[Allier]] [[Departments of France]]. Situated on the left side of [[Allier (river)|Allier River]], it faces the town and its historic quarter. The museum includes the historic building, which had been partially destroyed during [[World War II]]{{cite web | url=http://www.cncs.fr/le-CNCS/decouvrir-le-cncs/historique | title=Historique | publisher=Centre National du Costume de Scene | accessdate=16 December 2013}} and was restored by François Voinchet, Architect of Historic Monuments for the museum.{{cite web | url=http://www.latribunedelart.com/le-centre-national-du-costume-de-scene-de-moulins-une-realisation-exemplaire | title=Le Centre National du Costume de Scène de Moulins: une réalisation exemplaire | publisher=La Tribune de l'Art | accessdate=16 December 2013}} Villars, named for the native military officer, [[Claude Louis Hector de Villars|Marshal Villars]] (1653–1734), was built during the reign of [[Louis XV of France|Louis XV]]. The 18th century [[Historical Monument|historical monument]]{{Base Mérimée|PA00093231}} Caserne ou quartier Villars, actuellement centre national du costume de scène was used as a cavalry barracks.{{cite book|author=Philip Jodidio|title=Architecture D'aujourd'hui|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kl9Shbs2S9cC&pg=PT533|year=2004|publisher=Taschen|isbn=978-3-8228-2935-6|page=533}}{{cite web | url=http://www.ville-moulins.fr/Centre-National-du-Costume-de,20.html | title=Centre National du Costume de Scene (French, translated in part using translate.google.com) | publisher=Ville de Moulins | accessdate=16 December 2013}} The interior of the museum was designed by [[Jean-Michel Wilmotte]] and Jacques Brudin. A new {{convert|1730|sqm|sqft}} building, was built for conservation of the centre's collection. ==Overview== The museum is the first structure, in France or abroad, to be entirely dedicated to [[scenography]] and [[costume]] heritage. Its mission is to preserve, study and increase the value of a [[Collection (artwork)|collection]] of 10,000 [[theatre]], [[opera]] and [[ballet]] costumes. It also shows paintings, on loan from the [[Bibliothèque nationale de France|Bibliothèque Nationale de France]] (National Library of France), the [[Comédie-Française]] and the [[Opéra de Paris]] (Paris Opera).{{cite web | url=http://www.saatchigallery.com/museums/museum-profile.php/Centre+National+Du+Costume+De+Scene/970.html | title=Centre National du Costume de Scene | publisher=Saatchi Gallery | accessdate=16 December 2013}}{{cite book|author1=Jean-Paul Labourdette, Dominique Auzias|author2=Sandrine Bavard|author3=Aurélia Riss|title=Petit Futé Vacances avec les enfants|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EMHCffAns44C&pg=PA46|date=6 May 2009|publisher=Petit Futé|isbn=978-2-7469-2513-7|page=46}}{{#tag:ref|Saatchi states that the collection hold 7,110 costumes, rather than the 10,000 states in the book by Labourdette and Auzias.|group="nb"}} The museum has four areas: the reserves, exhibition halls, library and the training center. There is a gallery of temporary exhibitions {{convert|1,500|sqm|sqft}} behind eight windows. A large room showcases costumes in a [[scenography]] context. It also has educational spaces, an [[auditorium]] and a documentation center. Its restaurant was decorated by [[Christian Lacroix]], and it has a museum shop. ==Collections== ===Nureyev collection=== The museum has a collection of [[Rudolf Nureyev]]'s costumes, as requested in his will to be a "place of memory". Nureyev, who has been the [[Paris Opera Ballet]] director had wished to have his collection placed in a museum in Paris, but suitable locations could not be found. So, his collection was placed in the museum in this Auvergne region museum, which is about 3 hours by train from Paris. It is "a permanent collection that offers visitors a sense of his exuberant, vagabond personality and passion for all that was rare and beautiful."{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/12/arts/dance/at-a-french-museum-peeks-at-nureyevs-world.html?_r=0 | title=At a French Museum, Peeks at Nureyev’s World | work=New York Times | date=11 December 2013 | accessdate=16 December 2013 | author=Roslyn Sulcas}} The collection has historical artifacts from Nureyev's career including film and photograph material, in addition to 70 costumes.{{cite news | author=Sarah Kaufman | title=Nureyev's Genius, Seen in Fragments of His Life. | work=The Washington Post (via HighBeam Research, subscription required) | publisher=Washingtonpost Newsweek Interactive | date=7 November 2012 | accessdate=16 December 2013 | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-33856062.html}} {{quote|Nureyev sought a matador look, with a snug-fitting jacket cut short to lengthen his legs. The armhole seam had to be exactly placed so his movements would not be hindered. He favored details that underscored artistic themes. A silver-blue jacket for his Prince Siegfried from the first act of a 1984 ''[[Swan Lake]]'' echoes the watery locale where the hero meets his true love, with metallic threads flowing over the shoulders like rapids. For ''[[Don Quixote]],'' Nureyev preferred a billowing sleeve, as evidenced by a creation from Greek designer Nicholas Georgiadis in rust, wine and gold. The velvet cascades of the women's dresses, trimmed in coins and tassels, hint at the choreography's noisy fury.|Sarah Kaufman, The Washington Post}} It was shown the [[De Young Museum]] in [[San Francisco, California]] through 17 February 2013 in a show entitled ''Rudolf Nureyev: A Life in Dance.'' ===Stage costumes=== Several stage companies and theatres, including the [[Comédie Française]] and [[Paris Opera|National Opera in Paris]], send their costumes to the museum after their final show. At the museum they are available to be exhibited and preserved. They are also available to researchers and students for study.{{cite web | url=http://www.vichy-spa-hotel.com/about-us/partners/centre-national-du-costume-de-scene | title=Centre National du Costume de Scene | publisher=Vichy Spa Hôtel Les Célestins | accessdate=16 December 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217021010/http://www.vichy-spa-hotel.com/about-us/partners/centre-national-du-costume-de-scene | archivedate=17 December 2013 | df= }}{{cite AV media | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qkEMNk1Avfk | title=Centre national du Costume de Scène de Moulins (French) | publisher=Youtube.com}} ==Past exhibitions== Previous exhibitions have included: {{div col}} * Best in Show * [[Théodore de Banville]] * I love the military * [[Christian Lacroix]], Costume * [[Jean-Paul Gaultier]] - [[Régine Chopinot]]: The Parade * Thousand and One Nights * Son in flowers, garden scenes * [[Rudolf Nureyev]] * [[Russian opera]]s {{div col end}} ==See also== * [[Costume Museum of Canada]] * [[Costume Museum (Kastoria)]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|group="nb"}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.cncs.fr Official site] (French) * [http://www.cncs.fr/the-CNCS/discover-the-CNCS/mission Official site] (English) * [https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/beta/partner/centre-national-du-costume-de-sc%C3%A8ne Centre national du costume de scène at Google Cultural Institute] {{Textile museums}} [[Category:Theatre museums]] [[Category:Museums in Allier]] [[Category:Fashion museums in France]] [[Category:Costume museums]] [[Category:Monuments historiques of Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Moulins, Allier]]

'''Chamber theatre''' is a method of adapting literary works to the stage using a maximal amount of the work's original text and often minimal and suggestive settings.
In chamber theater, [[narration]] is included in the performed text and the [[narrator]] might be played by multiple actors. Professor Robert S. Breen (1909-1991) introduced "Chamber Theater" to his Oral Interpretation Classes at [[Northwestern University]] in 1947.<ref name="O'Neill2014">{{cite book|author=Cecily O'Neill|title=Dorothy Heathcote on Education and Drama: Essential Writings|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AqBeBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA63|date=27 August 2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-63250-4|pages=63–}}</ref>
Northwestern’s Professor of Performance Studies [[Frank Galati]], who studied chamber theater with Dr. Breen, has directed highly acclaimed chamber theater productions for the [[Goodman Theater]] and [[Steppenwolf Theatre Company|Steppenwolf Theater]] companies in Chicago. Galati’s chamber theater adaptation of [[John Steinbeck]]’s ''[[The Grapes of Wrath]]'' won two [[Tony Awards]] on Broadway.<ref name="Fisher2011">{{cite book|author=James Fisher|title=Historical Dictionary of Contemporary American Theater: 1930-2010|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m6O5-spILIUC&pg=PA286|date=1 June 2011|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-8108-7950-8|pages=286–}}</ref>
One of the most famous and elaborate examples of chamber theatre is [[David Edgar (playwright)|David Edgar]]'s ''[[The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby (play)|The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby]]'', in which [[Charles Dickens]]' characters narrate themselves in [[Grammatical person|third person]]. Set pieces are carried in and taken away during the performance, rather than between scenes, and objects may be represented in a [[mimetic]] manner.<ref name="Cortland2001">{{cite book|author=Thomas S. Hischak Professor of Theatre State University of New York at Cortland|title=American Theatre : A Chronicle of Comedy and Drama, 1969-2000: A Chronicle of Comedy and Drama, 1969-2000|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1aSM__nVScAC&pg=PA192|date=12 January 2001|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|isbn=978-0-19-535255-9|pages=192–}}</ref> ==See also== *[[Chamber play]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chamber Theatre}} [[Category:Theatrical genres]]

{{Multiple issues| {{More footnotes|date=May 2015}} {{Refimprove|date=May 2015}} }}
[[Image:Cremorne The Dancing Platform at Cremorne Gardens by Phoebus Levin 1864.jpg|thumb|''The Dancing Platform at Cremorne Gardens'' by [[Phoebus Levin]], 1864.]] [[Image:Chelsea cremorne gardens 1.jpg|thumb|One of the original gates from Cremorne Gardens, recently restored and installed at the vestigial site. (January 2006)]] [[Image:Cremore Gardens Ashburnham Pavilion Cremore Gardens ILN 1858.jpg|thumb|The Ashburnham Pavilion in 1858.]] [[Image:Cremorne Gardens 1865 OS map.JPG|thumb|An 1865 map showing Cremorne Gardens. [[Kings Road]] is at the top and the [[River Thames]] is at the bottom right.]]
'''Cremorne Gardens''' were popular [[pleasure gardens]] by the side of the [[River Thames]] in [[Chelsea, London]]. They lay between Chelsea Harbour and the end of the King's Road and flourished between 1845 and 1877; today only a vestige survives, on the river at the southern end of [[Cheyne Walk]]. Cremorne is also a ward of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea. The population of the ward at the 2011 Census was 7,974.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadKeyFigures.do?a=7&b=13688894&c=Cremorne&d=14&e=62&g=6331147&i=1001x1003x1032x1004&o=362&m=0&r=1&s=1476542614333&enc=1|title=Kensington and Chelsea Ward population 2011|accessdate=15 October 2016|publisher=Office for National Statistics |work=Neighbourhood Statistics}}</ref>
==History== Originally the property of [[Theophilus Hastings, 7th Earl of Huntingdon|the Earl of Huntingdon]] (c. 1750), father of [[Steele's Aspasia]], who built a mansion here, the property passed through various hands into those of [[Thomas Dawson, 1st Viscount Cremorne|The 1st Viscount Cremorne]] (1725–1813), an [[Irish people|Irish]] peer from [[County Monaghan]], who greatly beautified it.
The name [[Cremorne (barony)|Cremorne]] is the name of a [[Barony (Ireland)|barony]], an old administrative unit, in [[County Monaghan]] in [[Ireland]]. It is an Anglicisation of what in modern [[Irish language|Irish]] is ''Críoch Mhúrn''. This roughly translates as the 'Bounds of Mourne', from the territorial domain of an ancient clan or sept called Mughdorna in [[Old Irish]]. The name is cognate with the [[Mourne Mountains|Mountains of Mourne]].
The property was sold by the Dawson family, [[Earl of Dartrey|Barons Cremorne]], in 1831 to a Baron de Berenger,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jackson|first1=Hazelle|title=Who to Cremorne Would Not Gladly Repair? A brief history of Cremorne Gardens, Chelsea|url=http://www.londongardenstrust.org/features/cremorne.htm|website=London Park and Gardens Trust|publisher=London Parks & Gardens Trust|accessdate=3 January 2016}}</ref> who was a convicted fraudster whose real name was Charles Random. de Berenger converted the site into a sports facility, called The Stadium, and became a proponent of self-defence techniques.<ref>{{cite web|title=Baron Charles de Berenger’s “Defensive Gymnastics” (1838)|url=http://www.bartitsu.org/index.php/2010/05/baron-charles-de-berengers-defensive-gymnastics-1838/|website=The Bartitsu Society|publisher=The Bartitsu Society|accessdate=3 January 2016|date=22 August 2008}}</ref> The business failed in 1843, but not before de Berenger had added some attractions of pleasure gardens of the time, including hosting a balloon ascent in 1838. For two years the gardens opened for summer, including an opening festival billed as "Pie de Nie" with Balloon ascent,<ref>{{cite journal|title=Cremorne House and Cremorne Gardens|journal=The Morning Post|date=June 19, 1845|issue=23222|pages=2|location=London, England|quote=Mr Littlejohn, late of the Rosherville Gardens ... has the honour to announce that he will open the Tavern, Park and Gardens of Cremorne for the season}}</ref> for instance, were held, and the property was sold in 1845. James Ellis took over the license in January 1845.<ref>{{cite journal|title=SURREY SESSIONS|journal=Daily News|date=March 17, 1846|issue=48|url=http://infotrac.galegroup.com/galenet/sid|location=London, England}}</ref> The twelve acre site was then developed by James Ellis into a proprietary place of entertainment and spectacle, being popular as such from 1845 to 1877. The Cremorne Gardens occupied a large site running between the Thames and the [[King's Road]]. Opened in 1845, they were noisy and colourful pleasure gardens featuring restaurants, entertainments, dancing and balloon ascents, and could be entered from the north gate on Kings Road or another by the Cremorne Pier on the river.
The famous artist [[James Abbott McNeill Whistler]] painted several nocturnes of Cremorne Gardens between 1872 and 1877. He was a resident of Cheyne Walk, a mere few hundred yards from the Gardens. His painting Cremorne Gardens No 2 is full of fashionable and active figures and parallels to some extent the ‘modern life’ paintings of his French associates Manet and Tissot with whom he was in close contact during the early 1870s. Cremorne Gardens was doubtless a most attractive location, not only for its light displays but also for the brilliant array of fashionable people who gathered there. They provided the setting for Nocturne in Black and Gold: the Firewheel and Nocturne in Black and Gold: the Falling Rocket of c.1874, the latter resulting in the [[James_Abbott_McNeill_Whistler#Ruskin_trial|Whistler versus Ruskin trial of 1878]].
Walter Greaves was the son of a Chelsea boat-builder who used to ferry Turner across the river; Walter and his brother Harry also performed the same service for Whistler, and in about 1863 became his unpaid studio assistants and pupils. They adored Whistler, accompanied him wherever he went, imitated his dress and manner, made the frames for his canvases, bought his materials and prepared his colours. Walter said; “He taught us to paint, and we taught him the waterman’s jerk”. Their close association lasted well into the 1890s, Whistler favouring Walter as he was the more gifted of the two brothers. Two of his most successful images were Regatta at Hammersmith Bridge and Chelsea under Snow; like Whistler he concentrated on areas around the Thames. He died in poverty, having been taken in by the Charterhouse.
Greaves chooses to depict Whistler near the Crystal Platform. A reporter in the Illustrated London News (30 May 1857) admired the structure’s “inclosing ironwork...enriched, by Defries and Son, with devices in emerald and garnet cut-glass drops, and semicircles of lustre and gas jets, which have a most brilliant effect.” The pavilion was about three hundred and sixty feet in circumference. It was encrusted with ornamental pillars, gas jets, and over forty plate-glass mirrors in black frames. In the upper portion of the pagoda (seen here), where the orchestra played, there were seventeen gas lit chandeliers.
This particular feature of the Gardens was clearly a favourite with Greaves as he chose to depict it on several occasions, for example The Dancing Platform, Cremorne Gardens (1870s) and in an etching of this period, which depicts the same view as Whistler in the Cremorne Gardens. In the former Whistler is depicted as the natty flaneur, striding along with and yet separate from the crowd. In the latter Whistler is seated but maintains the image of flaneur, the impartial, non-judgmental observer of contemporary life. He leans to one side to acknowledge a fellow dandy, much to the impatience of the young woman who stands at his table. Cremorne Gardens rapidly acquired a reputation as the territory of the demi-monde frequented by women of questionable morals. His associate could buy such a woman; this is implied by his indifference towards her, the attention of the passing woman as well as the undisguised stare of the gentleman at the railing.
Whistler and the Greaves family were frequent visitors before the gardens closed in 1877. Cremorne Gardens never acquired the fashionable fame of [[Vauxhall Gardens]], and finally became so great an annoyance to some of the more influential residents in the neighbourhood that a renewal of its licence was refused, and most of the site of the gardens was soon built over. The name survives in Cremorne Road.
[[Donald James Wheal]], in his first-person memoir of life in working-class [[Chelsea, London|Chelsea]], [https://www.amazon.co.uk/exec/obidos/ASIN/0099474166 World's End] gives a lively account of the almost-forgotten history and destruction of Cremorne Gardens.
==Today== A vestige of the gardens survives next to the Thames, just east of [[Lots Road power station]]. It is largely paved over, and there is little to suggest the grand scale of the original gardens, though it still has two attached jetties, an echo of the landing stages where visitors to the original pleasure gardens would arrive by boat. Recently, one of the original grand iron gates from the gardens has been restored and stands on the current site {{coord|51.47983|N|0.17834|W|}}. A [[Cremorne Gardens, Melbourne|Cremorne Gardens]] was also established in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]].
On 13 September 2010 Thames Water published its preferred sites for building work on its [[Thames Tideway scheme|Thames Tideway]] super sewer. Thames Water originally proposed that an access road cut straight through Cremorne Gardens. [https://web.archive.org/web/20110718195027/http://www.thamestunnelconsultation.co.uk/pdf/Cremorne_Wharf_Foreshore.pdf]
Cremorne Gardens secured a Green Flag award for the first time in 2010 as one of the best green spaces in England. Councillor [[Nicholas Paget-Brown]], Cabinet Member for Environment and Leisure Services, attended the flag raising ceremony at Cremorne Gardens at the end of July along with the Mayor of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor James Husband. [https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:EOcHzNQ5WVAJ:www.rbkc.gov.uk/newsroom/idoc.ashx%3Fdocid%3Dbb421935-29cf-4f80-b90a-1f2448f8994e%26version%3D-1+by+election+cremorne+gardens+conservatives&hl=en&gl=uk&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESg0m7-2Svk-LrVVd5gyLdu4ozKFfw8ei5v9LSi-VhFLBK6ki814qhy8DFsqFPUk3HtdPyoaIKICOvJ2PGvcH4hrZoQGAS2VpNK67vQce5PI1VQ4ozgPP94iHb2_KjnA1Vht9hZz&sig=AHIEtbR6lsCJXB4lwo8UdSW7PevDyUz6lQ]
Local Conservative Kensington and Chelsea Councillors and residents have promised to try to save the Gardens from use as an access road to build the Thames Tunnel. [http://kensington.londoninformer.co.uk/2011/01/residents-battle-to-save-garde.html]. Phil Stride representing Thames Water stated "We are happy to work with the council to use whatever access route they can help us find." Early in 2011, the Lots Road Waste Centre owned by the Council ceased operation. The former Waste Centre is closer to the proposed Tideway Tunnel, therefore is an alternative site for the access road. However, Cremorne Gardens is still listed as the preferred site on the Thames Water website even though it is the Council's decision. [http://www.thameswater.co.uk/cps/rde/xchg/corp/hs.xsl/10115.htm]
In 2014, Cremorne Gardens was again under threat from the local council which suggested to Transport For London that there be a "Chelsea West" station on Kings Road near World's End and on the site of the Cremorne Estate for Crossrail Two. Cremorne Gardens would have been destroyed to use as the building site for the station. After a huge outcry from residents, the council abandoned its support for Chelsea West.<ref>{{cite web|last=Culbertson |first=Alix |url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/news/local-news/exclusive-crossrail-2-station-could-7333441 |title=Exclusive: Crossrail 2 station could destroy hundreds of homes built after Second World War |publisher=Getwestlondon.co.uk |date=2014-06-26 |accessdate=2015-05-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Culbertson |first=Alix |url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/news/local-news/neighbours-fear-council-social-cleansing-7392583 |title=Neighbours fear council 'social cleansing' with Crossrail 2 plans |publisher=Getwestlondon.co.uk |date=2014-07-08 |accessdate=2015-05-20}}</ref>
==In popular culture== The BBC drama ''[[Desperate Romantics]]'' regularly depicted the [[Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood]] meeting prostitutes in Cremorne Gardens.
In [[Strong Poison]], a [[Lord Peter Wimsey]] mystery, [[Dorothy L. Sayers]] named a character Cremorna Garden. Cremorna was an actress of dubious repute, no doubt so named after the garden's racy reputation. In "Coral" by Compton Mackenzie (1925) in which Coral Avery, an upper-class girl, falls in love with her chauffeur, she gets him to drive down the Embankment to the Cremorne Arms at Chelsea reach, where they declare their love for each other.
==References and sources== {{Commons category|Cremorne Gardens, London}} ;References {{reflist}} ;Sources *[http://www.victorianlondon.org/entertainment/cremorne.htm The Victorian Dictionary] *[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.asp?compid=45224 Cremorne Gardens in Old and New London, Volume 5 (1878)] *[http://www.bdonline.co.uk/buildings/sarah-wigglesworth-boxes-clever-at-cremorne-riverside-centre/3103388.article bdonline] {{EB1911|wstitle=Cremorne Gardens|volume=7|page=408}}
{{coord |51|28|48|N|0|10|42|W|type:landmark_region:GB|display=title}}
