Wright]] * [[Maurice LaMarche]] * [[Kenneth Mars]] * [[Danny Cooksey]] * [[Jim Cummings]] * [[Bradley Pierce]] * [[Pat Carroll (actress)|Pat Carroll]] }} | theme_music_composer = {{Plainlist| * Dan Foliart * Mark Watters }} | opentheme = "Part of Your World", "Under the Sea", and "Kiss the Girl" | endtheme = "Under the Sea" | composer = {{Plainlist| * Dan Foliart * Mark Watters }} | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 3 | num_episodes = 31 | list_episodes = List of The Little Mermaid episodes | producer = {{Plainlist| * Jamie Mitchell * Tedd Anasti (co-producer) * Patsy Cameron (co-producer) * Traci Tolman Mars (assistant producer) * Donna Smith (assistant producer) }} | editor = Elen Orson | runtime = 22 minutes | company = {{Plainlist| * [[Walt Disney Television Animation]] }} | distributor = [[Walt Disney Television]] | channel = [[CBS]] | picture_format = Color | audio_format = Stereo | first_aired = {{Start date|1992|9|11}} | last_aired = {{End date|1994|11|26}} | preceded_by = ''[[The Little Mermaid (1989 film)|The Little Mermaid]]'' | followed_by = {{Plainlist| * ''[[The Little Mermaid II: Return to the Sea]]'' * ''[[The Little Mermaid: Ariel's Beginning]]'' }} }}
'''''Disney's The Little Mermaid''''' is an American animated television series produced by [[Disney Television Animation|Walt Disney Television Animation]] based on the [[The Little Mermaid (1989 film)|1989 Disney film of the same name]]. It features the adventures of [[Ariel (The Little Mermaid)|Ariel]] as a mermaid prior to the events of the film. This series is the first Disney television series to be spun off from a major animated film. Some of the voice actors of the film reprise their roles in the series, among them [[Jodi Benson]] as Ariel, [[Samuel E. Wright]] as Sebastian, [[Kenneth Mars]] as King Triton and [[Pat Carroll (actress)|Pat Carroll]] as Ursula. Other voice actors include [[Edan Gross]] and [[Bradley Pierce]] as Flounder, and [[Jeff Bennett (voice actor)|Jeff Bennett]] as Prince Eric.
''The Little Mermaid'' premiered in the fall of 1992 with the animated [[prime time]] special called "A Whale of a Tale", then moved to Saturday mornings. This series originally appeared on [[CBS]], with an original run from 1992 to 1994 (prior to Disney's purchase of rival [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]). [[Disney Channel]] reran the series from October 2nd, 1995 to September 7th, 2002 and again from September 5th, 2006, to July 4th, 2010. Some of the episodes contain musical segments, featuring original songs written for the series. The opening theme to the show is an instrumental combination of the songs "[[Part of Your World]]", "[[Under the Sea]]" and "[[Kiss the Girl]]". The overture for the stage musical of ''[[The Little Mermaid (musical)|The Little Mermaid]]'' is similar to this.
==Premise== ''The Little Mermaid'' television series is a prequel to the movie of the same name. The story is set before the events in the 1989 film, and follows Ariel's adventures as a mermaid still living under the sea with her father, Sebastian the [[crab]] and Flounder the [[Coral reef fish|fish]]. Various episodes highlight her relationships with her friends, father and sisters, and usually involve Ariel foiling the attempts of various enemies that intend ill harm to her or her kingdom. A prequel film, ''[[The Little Mermaid: Ariel's Beginning]]'', was released in 2008 containing events that contradict the television series (such as Ariel's youth and first meeting with Flounder), making the TV series and ''Ariel's Beginning'' independent continuities.
==Development== After the success of the 1989 movie, [[The Walt Disney Company]] planned to produce a children's television series for its Disney Channel cable outlet called "The Little Mermaid's Island." The proposed series would feature puppets from [[Jim Henson's Creature Shop]] interacting with a "live" Ariel. As the video release of ''The Little Mermaid'' soared in sales during 1990 and early 1991, Disney quietly dropped plans for "The Little Mermaid's Island" in favor of a more ambitious plan: an animated weekly series for the CBS network. The new show would concern the adventures of Ariel and her friends before the events in the movie.
Jamie Mitchell, an artist and graphic designer who worked on ''[[Disney's Adventures of the Gummi Bears]]'', was named the producer and director of the new series. Patsy Cameron and Tedd Anasti were the story editors and wrote almost all of the episodes for the show's second and third seasons. Their previous joint work included Hanna-Barbera's ''[[The Smurfs (TV series)|The Smurfs]]'', the animated ''[[Beetlejuice (TV series)|Beetlejuice]]'' and Disney's ''[[DuckTales]]''. Some of the artists and technicians on the feature film also contributed to the TV series. [[Mark Dindal]], chief of special animated effects for the movie, was a consultant for special effects on the TV show. Robby Merkin, who worked with [[Alan Menken]] and [[Howard Ashman]] on arranging the songs for the movie, worked as the arranger and music producer for the first season of the TV show.
Conscious of the worldwide acclaim for the movie's superior artistry, [[Disney Television Animation|Walt Disney Television Animation]] auditioned the best overseas animation studios. In the world of TV animation, farming most of the artwork out to Asian studios is an economic reality due to lower production costs and wages abroad. Studios in [[Korea]], Japan and the [[Philippines]] contributed to the series.
==Broadcast== The show's broadcast debut in September 1992 was in the form of a half-hour prime-time special, "The Little Mermaid: A Whale of a Tale."
Its Saturday morning debut came the very next day. The show's time slot was 8:30 a.m., following another new animated series, ''[[Fievel's American Tails]]'', based on the animated movie ''[[An American Tail]]''. ''The Little Mermaid'' series drew a fair bit of media attention, including more than one spot on [[Entertainment Tonight]], because it was the first series based directly on a Disney animated feature and was a rare television cartoon concerning a strong female character. The show kept its time slot the following year with its second season.
For the series' third season, the show was moved to the 8 a.m. time period and was the lead-in for a new Disney animated series, ''[[Aladdin (TV series)|Aladdin]]''. This was to be the show's last season in original production; CBS elected not to buy another batch of episodes. On October 2, 1995, [[Disney Channel]] began rerunning the show seven days a week.<ref name="Disney Channel premiere">''The Disney Channel Magazine'', Vol. 13, no. 5, October/November 1995: pp. 36, 46, 54.</ref> The show was broadcast on [[Disney Channel]] until 2010.It was also shown on [[Toon Disney]] until 2007. The series then aired on [[Disney Junior]] from the channel's launch in 2012 until 2014.
==Characters== {{main article|List of Disney's The Little Mermaid characters}}
=== From the 1989 film === *[[Ariel (Disney)|Ariel]] (voiced by [[Jodi Benson]]) – is the youngest daughter of the sea king. She loves singing and going on adventures. She also has developed [[magic (paranormal)|magic]] in season 2 (episode 9) to save her world. *[[Characters from Disney's The Little Mermaid#Flounder|Flounder]] (voiced by [[Edan Gross]] in season 1, and by [[Bradley Pierce]] in seasons 2–3) – Ariel's best friend, a bright yellow and blue colored [[Tropical fish|tropical reef fish]] who follows along on her adventures, and can be easily scared. *[[Characters from Disney's The Little Mermaid#Sebastian|Sebastian]] (voiced by [[Samuel E. Wright]]) – A small red [[Jamaica]]n-accented [[crab]] who acts as the king's adviser, court musician, a teacher, a scout leader and a baby-sitter-like figure for Ariel. *[[Characters from Disney's The Little Mermaid#King Triton|King Triton]] (voiced by [[Kenneth Mars]]) – is Ariel's father and ruler of Atlantica who protects his kingdom with his magic trident. *[[Characters from Disney's The Little Mermaid#Scuttle|Scuttle]] (voiced by [[Maurice LaMarche]]) – is a clumsy [[seagull]] who is friends with Ariel. He first appears in the episode "Scuttle". At first Ariel is afraid of him, but they become friends after he helps them rescue Sebastian.
*[[Characters from Disney's The Little Mermaid#Attina|Attina]] (voiced by [[Kath Soucie]]):
*[[Characters from Disney's The Little Mermaid#Aquata|Aquata]] (voiced by [[Mona Marshall]]),
*[[Characters from Disney's The Little Mermaid#Andrina|Andrina]] (voiced by [[Cathy Cavadini|Catherine Cavadini]]),
*[[Characters from Disney's The Little Mermaid#Arista|Arista]] (voiced by [[Mary Kay Bergman]]): Arista is one of Ariel's older sisters. She has blonde hair tied in a half ponytail hair style and has a red tail and red top.
*[[Characters from Disney's The Little Mermaid#Adella|Adella]] (voiced by [[Sherry Lynn]])
*[[Characters from Disney's The Little Mermaid#Alana|Alana]] (voiced by [[Kimmy Robertson]]) are Ariel's six older sisters.
*[[Characters from Disney's The Little Mermaid#Ursula|Ursula]] (voiced by [[Pat Carroll (actress)|Pat Carroll]]) is a powerful [[Mythological hybrid|cecaelian]] sea witch who occasionally antagonizes Ariel. *[[Characters from Disney's The Little Mermaid#Flotsam and Jetsam|Flotsam and Jetsam]] (voiced by [[Paddi Edwards]]) – They are Ursula's [[green moray|green moray eel]] informers who spy others and show Ursula what they are seeing with their magic yellow eye, they have one eye white and the other yellow. *[[Prince Eric]] (voiced by [[Jeff Bennett (voice actor)|Jeff Bennett]]) – Ariel's future husband. His first appearance is in the episode "Thingamajigger" and appears occasionally throughout the seasons with his dog, Max, as a puppy. Ariel first sees him saving a dolphin from a net, which technically makes this scene the first time she has ever seen Prince Eric, but does not know who he is. Eric also sees Ariel swimming on the surface for a couple of seconds but no one believed him.
===Original characters=== *[[List of Disney's The Little Mermaid characters#Urchin|Urchin]] (voiced by [[Danny Cooksey]]) – He is a young [[orphan]] [[merman|merboy]] and Ariel's friend. He shares her love for adventure and is unofficially her adopted brother, and at one point starts to develop romantic feelings for Ariel. * The Lobster Mobster (voiced by [[Joe Alaskey]]) – A [[red-violet]] [[lobster]] gangster following the style of the 1920s gangster stereotype and Da [[Shrimp]] (voiced by [[David Lander]]) is his sidekick. * Evil Manta (voiced by [[Tim Curry]]) – An evil man/[[manta ray]] hybrid who repeatedly tries to take over Atlantica. He has a son named Little Evil who Ariel befriends in the episode "A Little Evil". * Pearl (voiced by [[Cree Summer]]) – A spoiled, thrill-seeking mermaid whose actions often lead to Ariel, as well as herself, getting in trouble. *[[List of Disney's The Little Mermaid characters#Spot|Spot]] (voiced by [[Frank Welker]]) – A [[killer whale]] calf whom Ariel adopted and secretly raised in the palace. * Simon (voiced by [[Brian Cummings]]) - A lonely, but friendly [[Lavender (color)|lavender]] colored [[Sea serpent|sea dragon]] whom Ariel, Sebastian, and Flounder befriends with. *[[List of Disney's The Little Mermaid characters#Gabriella and Ollie|Gabriella]] – A [[deaf-mute]] [[Latino|Latina]] mermaid who dreams of being able to sing. Gabriella's sign language is translated by her [[blue]] [[octopus]] friend Ollie (who is voiced by [[Whit Hertford|Whitby Hertford]]). This character is based on a real person who was a fan of the show and died during its first season. * Moray (voiced by [[Dave Coulier]]) – A [[Variations of green#Dark green|dark green]] [[moray eel]] salesman and con-artist who occasionally sells items to Ariel that alternately help her or get her into trouble. * The [[List of Disney's The Little Mermaid characters#Crabscouts|Crabscouts]] (occasionally voiced by [[J. D. Daniels|J.D. Daniels]], [[Anndi McAfee]], [[Bradley Pierce]], [[Malachi Pearson]], and [[Whit Hertford|Whitby Hertford]]) – They are crab children, consisting of two boys and one girl, who are under the mentorship of Sebastian in a scout-like troop. * [[List of Disney's The Little Mermaid characters#Flo and Ebb|Flo and Ebb]] (voiced by [[Kath Soucie]] and [[Richard Karron]]) – Two [[brown]] [[alligator]] [[criminal]]s who appear in the episode "Beached". * The [[List of Disney's The Little Mermaid characters#Magical Wishing Starfish|Magical Wishing Starfish]] (voiced by [[Tony Jay]]) – A giant [[Sea star|starfish]] with a [[beard]] and [[Crown (headgear)|crown]] who only appears in the episode "Wish Upon A Starfish". * Emperor Sharga (voiced by [[Jim Cummings]]) – Ruler of the Sharkanians, the aggressive shark-people who live in Sharkania similar to the merfolk who live in Atlantica. Sharga wishes to take over Atlantica someday. *The Ancient Seaclops (voiced by [[Jim Cummings]]) – An ancient one-eyed sea monster whose primary objective is to sleep every 1,000 years and wants to see it through more than anything else. He gets very angry when he is woken up so abruptly by any loud noise and appeared in the episode "Calliope Dreams". *[[List of Disney's The Little Mermaid characters#Dudley|Dudley]] (voiced by [[Lawrence Montaigne]]) is an elderly [[sea turtle]] who serves as an assistant to King Triton other than Sebastian he walks on the Ocean floor unlike other sea turtles. *[[List of Disney's The Little Mermaid characters#Hans Christian Andersen|Hans Christian Andersen]] (voiced by [[Mark Hamill]]) – A fictionalised version of the author Hans Christian Andersen, who appears in the episode "Metal Fish" where he rides a fish-shaped [[Submarine]] and sees Ariel, which inspires him to write the story "The Little Mermaid". *[[List of Disney's The Little Mermaid characters#Archimedes|Archimedes]] (voiced by [[Rod McKuen]]) – A merman who knows about human things, appearing in "Metal Fish".
==Episodes== {{main|List of The Little Mermaid episodes}} {{:List of The Little Mermaid episodes}}
The series had a total of 31 episodes over three seasons. The first episode, "Whale of a Tale", has Ariel adopting Spot, a baby killer whale, when he is separated from his family. The episode "The Evil Manta" features a flashback to Ariel and Flounder's first meeting when they were younger, and the episode "Red" has King Triton magically reverting into a merboy, which gives Ariel a glimpse of how her father used to be when he was younger, and that they aren't so different after all.
In the episode "Metal Fish" Ariel saves a human, [[Hans Christian Andersen]], who is loosely based on the real life author of the original ''The Little Mermaid'', and the encounter inspired the character to "write" the story of ''The Little Mermaid''. A voice-over at the end of the episode by [[Kenneth Mars]], who voices King Triton, talks about the real Hans Christian Andersen, while the image on-screen is of Ariel sitting on a rock in the style of the Little Mermaid statue in [[Copenhagen]] harbor. This meta situation is repeated in ''[[The Legend of Tarzan (TV series)|The Legend of Tarzan]]'' episode "Tarzan and the Mysterious Visitor" where Tarzan meets his author [[Edgar Rice Burroughs]] who travels to Africa in search of inspiration for a new novel.

==Spin-off== From the series, was made into a spin-off as segment of the ''[[Marsupilami (1993 TV series)|Marsupilami]]'' series, starring Sebastian the crab, which is located outside the sea after the wedding between Ariel and Eric in the [[The Little Mermaid (1989 film)|film]].

{{Infobox company | name = The Muppets Studio, LLC | logo = The Muppets Studio logo.png | former_name = The Muppets Holding Company (2004–2007) | type = [[Subsidiary]] | parent = [[Walt Disney Parks, Experiences and Consumer Products]]
([[The Walt Disney Company]]) | foundation = {{Start date and age|2004|2|14}} | location_city = [[Los Angeles, California]] | location_country = [[United States]] | key_people = Debbie McClellan (Vice President) | num_employees = 5 (2015){{cite news|last1=Jurgensen|first1=John|title=The Muppets Grow Up and Go Back to Prime Time|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-muppets-grow-up-and-go-back-to-prime-time-1441918442|accessdate=September 28, 2015|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=September 10, 2015}} | industry = Entertainment | products = ''[[The Muppets]]''
''[[Bear in the Big Blue House]]'' | revenue = | operating_income = | homepage = {{official website|muppets.disney.com}} }} '''The Muppets Studio, LLC''', formerly '''The Muppets Holding Company, LLC''', is a wholly owned entertainment subsidiary of [[Walt Disney Parks, Experiences and Consumer Products]], formed in 2004 through [[The Walt Disney Company]]'s acquisition of [[The Muppets]] and ''[[Bear in the Big Blue House]]'' [[intellectual properties]] from [[The Jim Henson Company]]. ==Background== In the late-1980s, [[Jim Henson]] had been in talks with Disney [[CEO]] [[Michael Eisner]] to sell [[The Jim Henson Company|Jim Henson Productions]] to the Walt Disney Company.{{cite news|last=Givens|first=Bill|title=The Mouse & The Frog|url=http://www.muppetcentral.com/articles/archives/1990_mouse_frog.shtml|accessdate=20 February 2013|newspaper=Animation Magazine|date=Spring 1990}} In August 1989, the two officially announced a deal for Disney to purchase Jim Henson Productions for $150 million.{{cite news|last1=Swansburg|first1=John|title=Muppet Man|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/08/books/review/jim-henson-the-biography-by-brian-jay-jones.html?_r=0|accessdate=September 28, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=December 6, 2013}} The deal fell through several months after Jim Henson's death in 1990.{{cite news |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,287872,00.html|archiveurl= |archivedate= |title=The Death of Jim Henson |first=Ty|last=Burr|date=1997-05-16 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |accessdate=2012-02-07}} Despite the collapse of the merger deal, by 1992, Disney and Jim Henson Productions had already struck a number of deals: *Exclusive domestic rights to Henson theme park attractions in the western U.S. until May 1994 plus 2 year non-exclusively, including the design of two Muppet attractions at [[Walt Disney World]] *[[Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment|Buena Vista Home Video]]'s worldwide distribution rights to Henson's 300 hours of programming and a financing deal for up to 3 home video projects *Certain cable television distribution rights for [[Disney Channel]] until 1997 *International distribution rights for existing TV programming in free broadcast, cable or pay-per-view markets *Theatrical distribution for ''[[The Muppet Christmas Carol]]'' (1992) and ''[[Muppet Treasure Island]]'' (1996) *[[Dinosaurs (TV series)|''Dinosaurs'']] co-production{{cite news|title= Jim Henson's Children Put Together a String of Big Deals to Keep Alive|work= The Los Angeles Times|date=1992-07-26|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1992-07-26/business/fi-5359_1_jim-henson|accessdate=2010-10-18|first=David|last=Willman}} *In 1996, the Jim Henson Company produced ''[[Muppets Tonight]]'' for [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], which had just been acquired by Disney.{{cite news|last=Goldberg|first=Lesley|title='Muppets' Revived at ABC With 'Big Bang Theory' Co-Creator|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/muppets-revived-at-abc-big-786193|accessdate=April 6, 2015|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=April 3, 2015}} The Henson family subsequently sold the entirety of the Jim Henson Company to German conglomerate [[Constantin Medien|EM.TV]] in 2000. In 2003, the Henson family repurchased The Jim Henson Company from EM.TV.{{cite news|last=Barnes|first=Brooks|title=Fuzzy Renaissance|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/21/movies/21barn.html?pagewanted=all |accessdate=29 December 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=18 September 2008}} ==History== ===Muppets Holding Company=== Eisner, still interested in the Muppet properties, re-opened negotiations with the Hensons and announced the purchase of ''The Muppets'' and ''Bear in the Big Blue House'' assets from [[The Jim Henson Company]] for $75 million on February 17, 2004. The acquired Muppet assets were then placed into The Muppets Holding Company with Chris Curtin as general manager within [[Disney Consumer Products]].{{cite news|last=Masters|first=Kim|title=Kermit as Mogul, Farting Fozzie Bear: How Disney's Muppets Movie Has Purists Rattled|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disney-muppets-jason-segel-amy-adams-jim-henson-250805?page=3|accessdate=20 August 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=20 October 2011|pages=3 of 4}} A new website was launched in November 2004 and the Muppets made an appearance on the 2004 Christmas episode of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. The first Muppet production under full Disney control, ''[[The Muppets' Wizard of Oz]]'', went into production immediately and aired on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] in May 2005.{{cite news|title=Disney's plan to relaunch the Muppets|url=http://www.muppetcentral.com/news/2005/051905.shtml|accessdate=20 February 2013|newspaper=Muppet Central.com|date=May 19, 2005|agency=AP}} On July 30, 2005, Animal and Pepe the King Prawn made appearance on The [[X Games]] 11 Preview show of All Access on [[ESPN2]].{{cite web|last1=Cave|first1=Steve|title=THE MUPPETS GET A TASTE OF THE X GAMES|url=http://skateboard.about.com/od/events/a/XGames11Muppets.htm|website=About Sports|publisher=About.com|accessdate=February 24, 2015}} Bear's first appearance under Disney's control was in the reality show, ''[[Breakfast With Bear]]'' in 2005.{{cite news|last1=Crosby|first1=Sherry Joe|title=When a Bear Comes to Breakfast|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-133427545.html|accessdate=February 24, 2015|work=Daily News|publisher=HighBeam Research.|date=November 25, 2013|location=Los Angeles, CA}} A fiftieth birthday tour for Kermit, "Kermit's World Tour" was planned with leadership changes made just days before the tour began. The tour made its initial three stops before being canceled: [[Kermit, Texas]], [[Johnson Space Center]] tour and cake with [[The Rockettes]] at [[Radio City Music Hall]], NYC. Following Eisner's exit from Disney, new CEO [[Bob Iger]] removed the head of the Muppets Holding Company and several senior staff members hand-picked by Eisner.{{cite news|last=Jim|first=Hill|title=Monday MouseWatch : Will the third time be the charm with Disney's Muppet revival project?|url= http://jimhillmedia.com/editor_in_chief1/b/jim_hill/archive/2007/04/30/monday-mousewatch-will-the-third-time-be-the-charm-for-disney-s-muppet-revival-project.aspx |accessdate=20 February 2013 |newspaper=jimhillmedia.com |date=April 29, 2007}} The Muppets Holding Company was then paired with [[Baby Einstein]] (before it was acquired by [[Kids II, Inc.]] in 2013) under Senior Vice President and General Manager R. Russell Hampton, Jr.{{cite news|last1=Suddath|first1=Claire|title=Meep Meep TV|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-17/new-muppets-sitcom-looks-to-take-prime-time|accessdate=September 29, 2015|work=Bloomberg Businessweek|date=September 17, 2015}} ABC, in October 2005, commissioned ''America's Next Muppet'', a script and five script outlines,{{cite web | last = Schneider | first = Michael| title = Muppets pull strings at ABC | publisher = Variety | date = 2005-10-25 | url = https://variety.com/2005/scene/news/muppets-pull-strings-at-abc-1117931517/ | accessdate = 2007-09-24 }}{{cite news|title='Muppets' may return to primetime TV|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2005-10-25-muppets_x.htm|accessdate=February 24, 2015|work=USA Today|agency=AP|date=October 25, 2005}} but ABC was reluctant to green light ''America's Next Muppet'', and it never got out of the planning stage. Muppet Holding's new general manager instead licensed the Muppets out to [[TF1]], a French television network, to produce ''Muppet TV'' in September 2006.{{cite web | last =James | first =Alison | title =Les Muppets on a French roll | publisher = Variety | date =September 17, 2006 | url = https://variety.com/2006/scene/news/les-muppets-on-a-french-roll-1117950189/# | accessdate = November 25, 2013 }} ===The Muppets Studio=== In 2006, the Muppets Holding Company was transferred from the Disney Consumer Products unit to [[The Walt Disney Studios (production company)|The Walt Disney Studios]]; with studio executives passing on oversight, the unit was placed in the special events group. That same year, Disney contracted with [[Puppet Heap]] to rebuild, maintain, and create puppet characters for the Muppets Studio. In April 2007, the Muppets Holding Company changed its name to The Muppets Studio under new leadership by Special Events Group [[Senior vice president|SVP]] Lylle Breier. In 2008, The Muppets Studio began a licensing agreement with [[F.A.O. Schwarz]], to create a Muppet-themed boutique where customers can design their own Muppet. In 2013, [[Disney Theatrical Productions]] revealed that a show based on The Muppets was in active development and that a 15-minute show had been conducted by [[Thomas Schumacher]] to see how the technical components would work out.{{cite news|last=Cox|first=Gordon|title=Disney Theatrical Eyeing Muppets On Stage |url=https://variety.com/2013/legit/news/disney-theatrical-eyeing-muppets-on-stage-exclusive-1200495467/|accessdate=June 12, 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=June 11, 2013}} The company was transferred in 2014 to Disney's new media unit, [[Disney Consumer Products and Interactive Media]], specifically DCPI Labs.{{cite web|title=Kyle Laughlin |url= https://www.disneyconsumerproducts.com/Home/display.jsp?contentId=dcp_home_executives_global_kyle_laughlin |website= disneyconsumerproducts.com |publisher=Disney Consumer Products|accessdate=September 29, 2015}} On April 3, 2015, a series of shorts named ''Muppets Moments'' premiered on [[Disney Junior]]. The series features conversations between the Muppets and young children.{{cite news|last1=Kelley|first1=Seth|title=Kermit Talks to Kids in Disney Junior’s ‘Muppet Moments’|url=https://variety.com/2015/tv/news/disney-junior-muppet-moments-kermit-the-frog-1201454397/|accessdate=March 19, 2015|work=Variety|date=March 17, 2015}} By April, [[Bill Prady]] was commissioned to write a script for a new Muppets pilot with the title ''[[The Muppets (TV series)|The Muppets]]''.{{cite news|last=Goldberg|first=Lesley|title='Muppets' Revived at ABC With 'Big Bang Theory' Co-Creator|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/muppets-revived-at-abc-big-786193|accessdate=April 6, 2015|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=April 3, 2015}} A reboot of the Muppets is planned as of February 21, 2018, for [[Disney+]]{{cite news|last1=Goldberg|first1=Lesley|title=Disney Planning Another 'Muppets' Reboot for Its Streaming Service|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/disney-planning-muppets-reboot-streaming-service-1086800|accessdate=March 9, 2018|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=February 21, 2018|language=en}} to be run by [[BAMTech]] and scheduled to be launched in 2019.{{cite news|last1=Jarvey|first1=Natalie|title=BAMTech Taps Apple Veteran to Lead Disney OTT|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/bamtech-taps-apple-veteran-lead-disney-ott-1076109|accessdate=March 9, 2018|work=The Hollywood Reporter|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=January 19, 2018|language=en}} Disney Consumer Products and Interactive Media became part of [[Walt Disney Parks, Experiences and Consumer Products]] in a March 2018 company reorganization.{{cite news|last1=Wang|first1=Christine|title=Disney announces strategic reorganization, effective immediately|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/14/disney-announces-strategic-reorganization-effective-immediately.html|accessdate=March 14, 2018|work=CNBC|date=March 14, 2018}} ==Leadership== ;General manager *Chris Curtin, 2004–2005 *Russell Hampton, 2005–May 2006 *Lylle Breier, Fall 2006–2010 *Kyle Laughlin, 2014- ;Vice-president *Debbie McClellan{{cite news|last1=Spangler|first1=Todd|title=The Muppets Take YouTube in Video Mashups|url=https://variety.com/2015/digital/news/the-muppets-take-youtube-in-video-mashups-1201486637/|accessdate=May 4, 2015|work=Variety|date=May 4, 2015}} and Disney Channel stars: [[Miley Cyrus]], [[Ashley Tisdale]] and [[Jonas Brothers]](July 25, 2008) [https://variety.com/2008/tv/news/miley-cyrus-mee-19881/# Miley Cyrus meets the Muppets in Disney ‘Muppisodes’|url=https://variety.com/2013/digital/news/watch-the-muppets-star-in-new-series-of-muppisodes-1200926802/|accessdate=8 December 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=6 December 2013}} *''[[Muppets Most Wanted]]'' (2014) *''Disney Drive-On with the Muppets'' (August 1, 2014) 6 episodes on [[Disney Movies Anywhere]]{{cite news|last1=Graser|first1=Marc|title=Disney Launches The Muppets Digital {{refimprove|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox character | name = James Bolivar diGriz | series = | image = Stainless Steel Rat.jpg | caption = First cover printing to ''The Stainless Steel Rat'' by Harry Harrison | first = | last = | creator = [[Harry Harrison (writer)|Harry Harrison]] | portrayer = | nickname = Slippery Jim | alias = The Stainless Steel Rat | species = Human | gender = Male | occupation = [[Confidence trick|Con man]]
[[Bank robbery|Bank robber]]
[[Crime|Criminal mastermind]] | affiliation = | title = | family = | spouse = Angelina diGriz | children = | relatives = | nationality = }} '''James Bolivar diGriz''', alias "'''Slippery Jim'''" and "'''The Stainless Steel Rat'''", is a fictional character and the [[antihero]] of a series of [[comic science fiction]] [[novels]] written by [[Harry Harrison (writer)|Harry Harrison]]. ==Description== '''James Bolivar diGriz''' goes by many aliases, including "'''Slippery Jim'''" and "'''The Stainless Steel Rat'''". He is a futuristic [[confidence trick|con man]], [[thief]], and all-round rascal. He is charming and quick-witted. He is also a master of disguise and martial arts, an accomplished bank robber, a criminal mastermind, an expert on breaking and entering, and (perhaps most usefully) a skilled liar. Master of self-rationalization, the Rat frequently justifies his crimes by arguing that he is providing society with entertainment; and besides which, he only steals from institutions that have [[insurance]] coverage. He displays a strong sense of morality, albeit in a much more restricted sense than is traditional. For example, diGriz will steal without compunction, but deplores killing. The character was introduced in Harrison's short story "The Stainless Steel Rat", first published in 1957 in ''[[Analog Science Fiction and Fact|Astounding]]'' magazine. The story introduces the Rat, who has just carried out a successful larceny operation, and subsequently details a complex bank robbery the Rat pulls off with ease; however, he is outfoxed by the mysterious "Special Corps" — a crime-fighting organisation staffed with former criminals — and recruited by them in order to fight crime. Harrison used the story, with minor modifications, as the introduction to the series' first full-length novel, also called ''[[The Stainless Steel Rat (novel)|The Stainless Steel Rat]]''. Like other characters created by Harrison, the Rat is a speaker of [[Esperanto]] and advocates [[atheism]]. ==Books== There are 13 works in the Stainless Steel Rat series. {| class="wikitable" !Title !Release date !In-series chronology[http://www.michaelowencarroll.com/hh/queries.htm Michaelowencarroll.com] !Notes |- |''The Stainless Steel Rat'' |1961 |4 | *Large sections of the story first appeared in ''[[Analog Science Fiction and Fact|Astounding]]'' as two [[Novella|novelette]]s: ''The Stainless Steel Rat'' (1957) and ''The Misplaced Battleship'' (1960). These were reworked into the opening chapters of the novel.[http://www.iol.ie/~carrollm/hh/n02-ssrintro.htm Iol.ie] *re-issued in Hardcover (1970): Published Walker and Co., Jacket Illustrator Jack Gaughan (two variations), LC #74-103005 [First Edition] *re-issued in paperback (1986): {{ISBN|0-441-77924-7}} |- | colspan="4" | Jim believes he has pulled off a successful bank job, but is out-conned into working for the Special Corps, the elite law-enforcement and [[spy]] agency led by the former greatest crook in the Galaxy, Harold P. Inskipp, and composed mostly of ex-criminals like himself. He believes he has escaped from the Corps, and meets his love interest, Angelina - also a criminal genius, but lacking in Jim's relatively high moral codes and strictures against killing. She is attempting to have an illegal space battleship built on an otherwise peaceful planet. Angelina was born unattractive and committed crimes to pay for her transformation into a beautiful woman; her psychological traumas are treated when Jim captures her, but she retains her allure and her criminal tendencies and joins in the Special Corps. |- |''The Stainless Steel Rat's Revenge'' |1970 |5 | *re-issued in paperback (1986): {{ISBN|0-441-77912-3}} |- | colspan="4" | Jim and Angeline get married, but rapidly get involved in something that so far has proven impossible in the galaxy - the planet Cliaand has successfully been invading other worlds. Jim is sent to infiltrate and investigate, and discovers the mysterious gray Men behind Cliaand's success, encounters a world of feisty warrior women, and becomes father of twins (James and Bolivar). |- |''The Stainless Steel Rat Saves the World'' |1972 |6 | *First serialised in 1971 in [[If (magazine)|''If'' magazine]] in three parts. Parts 2 and 3 were titled, respectively, ''The Cast Iron Rat'' and ''The Stainless Steel Rat's Return''. (The latter should not be confused with the ''Return of...'' board game or ''...Rat Returns'' 2010 novel). *re-issued in paperback (1989): {{ISBN|0-441-77913-1}} |- | colspan="4" | A master criminal from the far future, "He", is attempting to erase the Special Corps from its timeline. Jim travels to 1975 Earth, and then to [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleonic]] [[England]], to stop He from destroying the timeline - but discovers that his own actions might have brought He into being! Finally He is trapped in a time loop, saving the Corps. |- |''The Stainless Steel Rat Wants You'' |1978 |7 | *re-issued in paperback (1985): {{ISBN|0-553-27611-5}} |- | colspan="4" | After freeing his family from various forms of incarceration (Angelina from the clutches of the Interstellar Income Tax people and his now teenage twins from their prison-like boarding school), Jim saves the all-[[human]] galaxy from invading [[extraterrestrial life|aliens]]. Additionally, two more Corps are revealed to exist - the Morality Corps whose main concern is that all human actions abide by their code of morality, and the Time Corps, who patrol [[spacetime|time]] itself to prevent any unauthorised tampering with the flow of time. Both new corps outrank the Special Corps; Inskipp is forced to work with them, but Jim (with some help from Angelina) finds a way to work around them. |- |''The Stainless Steel Rat for President'' |1982 |8 | *re-issued in paperback (1987): {{ISBN|0-553-27612-3}} |- | colspan="4" | Jim and Angelina enjoy a belated [[honeymoon]] on a planet run by a dictator who rigs elections to keep himself in office, so the Rat (with his family's help) sets himself up as a rival candidate. Very much a satire on [[banana republic]] politics and a parody of adventures set in [[Latin America]]. |- |''A Stainless Steel Rat Is Born'' |1985 |1 | *paperback (1986): {{ISBN|0-553-27942-4}} |- | colspan="4" | A novel chronicling the beginning of the Stainless Steel Rat's career. Jim intentionally gets caught trying to rob a bank so that he will go to jail where he can learn from the masters of crime, only to realize (too late) that the true masters would never get caught. |- |''The Stainless Steel Rat Gets Drafted'' |1987 |2 | *original hardback: {{ISBN|0-553-05220-9}} *re-issued in paperback (1991): {{ISBN|0-553-27307-8}} |- | colspan="4" | Takes place immediately following ''A Stainless Steel Rat Is Born''. Jim hunts the man who killed his mentor, but in the process must save a pacifist planet from an imminent attack by a military dictatorship led by the same man. |- |"The Golden Years of the Stainless Steel Rat" |1993 |13 |Published in ''Stainless Steel Visions'' by Harry Harrison (Tor 0-312-85245-2), a collection of 12 reprinted stories, one original. |- | colspan="4" | An original short story which finds Jim in Terminal Penitentiary, a prison where over-the-hill crooks are sent. |- |''The Stainless Steel Rat Sings the Blues'' |1994 |3 | *original hardback: {{ISBN|0-553-09612-5}} *paperback (1995): {{ISBN|0-553-56939-2}} |- | colspan="4" | The Stainless Steel Rat (in the same earlier timeline as ''Is Born'' and ''Gets Drafted'') goes to a prison colony planet to retrieve an alien artifact, which he must find in thirty days, or the slow-acting poison he was administered will take its effect. |- |''The Stainless Steel Rat Goes to Hell'' |1996 |9 | *original hardback: {{ISBN|0-312-86063-3}} *paperback (1998): {{ISBN|0-8125-5107-9}} |- | colspan="4" | In the later timeline (to which the stories have henceforth returned), Jim searches for his wife, who is abducted by a con man who preys on religious believers, swindling them out of their money and then enslaving them in his [[mining]] operation. |- |''The Stainless Steel Rat Joins the Circus'' |1999 |10 | *original hardback: {{ISBN|0-312-86934-7}} *paperback (2000): {{ISBN|0-8125-7535-0}} |- | colspan="4" | Jim is hired by a businessman to investigate thefts; the clues lead him to suspect a roaming [[circus (performing art)|circus]], which he infiltrates. |- |''The Stainless Steel Rat Returns'' |2010 |11 | *The first three chapters were published as ''The Stainless Steel Rat and the Pernicious Porcuswine'' in the anthology ''Gateways'' (2010), edited by [[Elizabeth Anne Hull]].[http://harryharrison.wordpress.com/2010/10/25/book-news-update/ Harryharrisonwordpress.com] *original hardback: {{ISBN|0-7653-2441-5}} |- | colspan="4" | The Stainless Steel Rat is living high on the hog on the planet of Moolaplenty when a long-lost cousin and a ship full of swine arrive to drain his bank account and send him and Angelina on a journey to wander the stars. |- |"The Stainless Steel Rat and The Misplaced Battleship" |2015 |12 | *Paperback: 34 pages *Publisher: Wilder Publications (September 28, 2015) *original hardback: {{ISBN|978-1515402374}} *paperback: {{ISBN|1515402371}} |- | colspan="4" | The Stainless Steel Rat goes undercover to find a stolen battleship. A short story originally published in 1960 and later expanded into the first novel of the series. |} : ''The Adventures of the Stainless Steel Rat'' (1978) anthologized the first three books: {{ISBN|0-425-04378-9}} : ''The Stainless Steel Rat Omnibus'' (2008) anthologized the first three books: {{ISBN|978-0-575-08171-0}} (Gollancz) Based on information in ''The Stainless Steel Rat Saves the World'' it is possible to work out when the timeline is set: James is sent 32,598 years into the past to 1975, making events happen in and around 34,573 (in the [[Far future in science fiction and popular culture|346th century]]) – although Professor Coypu also mentions that they are now using a different calendar to the [[Gregorian calendar]]. Specifics of the new calendar are never mentioned. ==Spin-offs== ===Comics=== ''The Stainless Steel Rat'', ''The Stainless Steel Rat Saves the World'' and ''The Stainless Steel Rat for President'' were adapted into comic strip form in early issues of ''[[2000 AD (comics)|2000 AD]]'', written by [[Kelvin Gosnell]] and drawn by [[Carlos Ezquerra]]. Ezquerra drew Jim with an appearance modelled on the actor [[James Coburn]]. They appeared in the following issues of ''2000 AD'': * ''The Stainless Steel Rat'', 12 episodes, 2000 AD progs 140–151 (Nov. 1979 to Feb. 1980). * ''The Stainless Steel Rat Saves the World'', 12 episodes, 2000 AD progs 166–177 (June to Sep. 1980). * ''The Stainless Steel Rat for President'', 12 episodes, 2000 AD progs 393–404 (Nov. 1984 to Feb. 1985). [http://www.2000ad.org/thrillpower/2kad7.html 2000AD Index] The first appearance of The Stainless Steel Rat in prog 140 was supposed to be preceded with a brief panel of explanation of who Jim was. However, an editorial error meant that the panel actually appeared at the end of the first episode, not the beginning. This prompted a letter to be printed in prog 148 from Harry Harrison himself pointing out the error, for which he won £3.{{cite book|last=MacManus|first=Steve|title=The Mighty One: My Life in the Nerve Centre|year=2016|publisher=Rebellion|isbn=978-1-78108-475-5|page=124}} These three stories were colorized and reprinted by [[Eagle Comics]] in 1985 and 1986 as a six-issue limited series. They were also collected in a [[trade paperback (comics)|trade paperback]] in July 2010 ({{ISBN|1906735514}}). ===Books=== ====Gamebook==== Harrison also produced a [[gamebook]] in the style of the [[Choose Your Own Adventure]] and [[Fighting Fantasy]] series, called ''You Can Be The Stainless Steel Rat'' ({{ISBN|0-441-94978-9}}), the reader being told that their decisions would "determine whether he or she can find Prof. Geisteskrank on the planet Skraldespand"Skraldespand" being the Danish word for garbage can. and bring him back before he activates a lethal new weapon". The reader generally cannot fail in this mission, regardless of his or her choices, although it is possible to get caught in an inescapable [[wiktionary:loop|loop]] at one point. ====Cameos==== In the tribute anthology ''[[Foundation's Friends]]'', Harrison wrote a story, ''The Fourth Law of Robotics'', which featured the Stainless Steel Rat in the setting of [[Isaac Asimov]]'s [[Robot series (Asimov)|''Robot'' series]]. ===Board game=== ''The Return of the Stainless Steel Rat'', a [[board game]] inspired by the character, was published by [[Simulations Publications|SPI]] in their magazine ''[[Ares (magazine)|Ares]]'' in the late 1970s. Designed by [[Greg Costikyan]], the game involved the Rat infiltrating a [[space station]] under hostile control.[http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/3531/the-return-of-the-stainless-steel-ra Boardgamegeek.com] ==Relationships== ===Angelina diGriz=== '''Angelina diGriz''' is a criminal mastermind much like the Rat, only less ethical and more willing to kill. As the Rat's first case for the Special Corps, he tracks Angelina down and ends up falling in love with her. After her capture, she undergoes [[psychosurgery|psycho surgery]] (not to be mistaken for "[[psychic surgery]]") to lessen her homicidal tendencies and she also joins the Corps; during that time she begins a relationship with the Rat that ends with them marrying in the last [[Pregnancy#Physiology|trimester]] of her pregnancy. She later assists on many of the Rat's adventures, often providing advice and solutions that Jim himself is unable to see. While she is no longer a heartless killer, her suppressed homicidal tendencies occasionally come out, especially when she sees another woman in close proximity to her husband. ===James and Bolivar diGriz=== '''James''' and '''Bolivar diGriz''' are the twin sons of the Rat and Angelina. The Rat missed the first six years of their life because of his adventures in time, but they share their father's attitudes and many of his skills. They end up marrying the same woman, who falls in love with both of them and gets herself duplicated into two identical women sharing one mind. ===Harold Peters Inskipp=== '''Harold Peters Inskipp''' is the director of the Special Corps and one of the most powerful men in the Galaxy. He recruits the Rat, but is frequently infuriated by his insubordinate attitude and tendency to go rogue - committing independent crimes for sheer enjoyment. The Special Corps is composed almost entirely of former criminals—Inskipp himself was a legendary fugitive known as "Inskipp the Uncatchable" before being recruited and eventually becoming the Corps' commander. ===Professor Coypu=== One of the few Special Corp members not taken from the criminal fraternity, '''Professor Coypu''' is a [[boffin]] who had developed a Time Helix device permitting [[time travel]] as well as a portal to [[parallel universe (fiction)|alternate realities]]. He also has a great deal of general scientific knowledge, and sent a copy of his mind with the Rat on his excursion to the 20th century to enable Jim to build a time helix and return to his native time. Coypu is rarely described, apart from having prominent [[Malocclusion|buck teeth]] - a trait he shares with his namesake, the [[Coypu]], or "nutria". ===The Bishop=== '''The Bishop''' was a master criminal on ''Bit O'Heaven'', the Stainless Steel Rat's home planet. He was a lot less physical in his capers than Jim but undertook robberies, always leaving as his [[Calling card (crime)|calling card]] a picture of the [[Bishop (chess)|bishop]] chess piece. He retired from robbery before Jim was born, focusing instead on computer crime, and Jim only learnt of his existence from a fellow prisoner while briefly in jail. Jim then contacted The Bishop by using his calling card in a robbery, however as a result The Bishop was forced out of retirement when he underestimated the Police's computer security systems after running a check on Jim himself. The Bishop eventually became Jim's mentor and taught him a great deal about their trade, as well as a code of ethics. Eventually Jim and The Bishop had to leave ''Bit O'Heaven'' and on their first off-planet adventure The Bishop was killed. As a parting gift he left Jim a note that he signed with his real name, although the name is not revealed to the reader. ===The Kekkonshiki=== '''The Kekkonshiki''', also known as "The Gray Men", are a human culture who initially prefer domination to coexistence. Their expertise lies in using technology to manipulate sentient minds, and they have manipulated both humans and aliens on a grand scale. Jim has experienced one of their techniques (in which a gray man agent seemingly severs his hands with an axe; this was an illusion). Jim has knowingly opposed them on two separate occasions (''The Stainless Steel Rat's Revenge'' & ''The Stainless Steel Rat Wants You'') however during conversation it is revealed by Kome that prior to ''The Stainless Steel Rat Wants You'' Jim has in fact thwarted their plans twice already, making this their third encounter. The text can also be read to say that the second time he thwarted their plans was with the alien invasion so the third encounter also happened during ''The Stainless Steel Rat Wants You'' when Jim invaded their home planet. They live on a harsh, icy world; this existence forced them to eliminate all emotion from their culture. This society is also completely patriarchal, with women being treated as nothing more than property. During Jim's interactions with Hanasu - a disgraced Kekkonshiki council leader - he persuades them to reinterpret their teachings, and they embark on a more peaceful co-existence with the rest of humanity. (Incidentally "Kekkonshiki" is the romanization of the Japanese word for "Marriage Ceremony" 結婚式.) ==In popular culture== The [[MIT class ring]], commonly referred to as "The Brass Rat", when cast in [[Celestrium]] (also known as jeweler's steel) is often referred to as "The Stainless Steel Rat" in reference to The Stainless Steel Rat series. The Chinese activist [[Liu Di]], writing under the screen name "Stainless Steel Rat" (不锈钢老鼠), became a high-profile symbol for democracy and free speech in China since her detention in November 2002. Her screen name is often translated as Stainless Steel Mouse. In ''[[The Librarians (2014 TV Series)|The Librarians]]'' episode "And the Happily Ever Afters", Flynn Carsen refers to Ezekiel Jones, a thief, "master of technologies" as the "Stainless Steel Rat". ==Reception== ''[[Galaxy Science Fiction|Galaxy]]'' reviewer Floyd C. Gale rated the first novel four stars out of five, saying "though pure entertainment, [it] underlines SF's role in providing speculative thought about potential problems."{{Cite magazine |last=Gale |first=Floyd C. |author= |last2= |first2= |date=June 1962 |title=Galaxy's 5 Star Shelf |department= |url=https://archive.org/stream/Galaxy_v20n06_1962-08#page/n189/mode/2up |magazine=Galaxy Science Fiction |pages=190-194 |type= }} ==References== ;Notes {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.iol.ie/~carrollm/hh/n02-.htm Stainless Steel Rat Series page] on Official website *{{isfdb series|id=576|title=The Stainless Steel Rat}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20041204120859/http://www.scifan.com/series/series.asp?SR_seriesid=508 Series listing] at SciFan {{Harry Harrison}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stainless Steel Rat, The}} [[Category:Science fiction book series]] [[Category:2000 AD comic strips]] [[Category:Novels by Harry Harrison]] [[Category:Fictional gentleman thieves]] [[Category:Fictional male martial artists]] [[Category:Fictional bank robbers]] [[Category:Picaresque novels]] [[Category:Fictional con artists]] [[Category:Comic science fiction]]

revision.text:
This is a timeline of the history of [[BBC Two]].
==1960s== *'''1964''' **4 January – Test transmissions begin for BBC Two.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1964-01-04|title=BBC Two England – 4 January 1964 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=21 November 2018}}</ref> **20 April – [[BBC Two]] starts broadcasting at 7.20pm.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1964-04-20|title=BBC Two England – 20 April 1964 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=21 November 2018}}</ref> **22 August – The first ''[[Match of the Day]]'' airs on [[BBC Two|BBC2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/8b92e63ea30143bab1ef6984b1599b31|title=Match of the Day – BBC Two England – 22 August 1964 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=21 November 2018}}</ref> The following episodes moved to BBC1.
*'''1965''' **9 January – ''[[Not Only... But Also]]'' debuts on BBC2.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/c225954a89e54e6c96e5ec16610bd6dd|title=Not Only.... But Also – – BBC Two England – 9 January 1965 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=9 November 2018}}</ref> **12 September – [[BBC Two Wales|BBC2 Wales]] goes on the air. To introduce the service, BBC2 airs a programme titled ''BBC-2 Comes to Wales'', featuring the [[Secretary of State for Wales]] [[Jim Griffiths|James Griffiths]], the Lord Mayor of Cardiff, the Deputy Mayor of Newport, Chairman of the Broadcasting Council for Wales Professor [[Glanmor Williams]], BBC2 Controller [[David Attenborough]], and BBC2 Wales Controller [[Alun Oldfield-Davies]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/0eeaa290284d457dbec644d0b267f099|title=BBC-2 Comes to Wales – BBC Two England – 12 September 1965 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=21 November 2018}}</ref> **31 October – [[BBC Two|BBC2]] in the [[Northern England|North of England]] goes on the air.
*'''1966''' **5 April – ''[[The Money Programme]]'' debuts on [[BBC Two|BBC2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/36fca513767940b8ada503a4f1774448|title=The Money Programme – BBC Two England – 5 April 1966 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=11 November 2018}}</ref> It continued to air until 2010. **11 June – [[BBC Two Northern Ireland|BBC2 Northern Ireland]] goes on the air. **9 July – [[BBC Two Scotland|BBC2 Scotland]] goes on the air, although much of England and some parts of Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland still cannot receive the channel. **2 October – The four-part serial ''[[Talking to a Stranger]]'', acclaimed as one of the finest [[United Kingdom|British]] television dramas of the 1960s, begins transmission in the ''[[Theatre 625]]'' strand on [[BBC Two|BBC2]].
*'''1967''' **1 January – Debut of [[The Forsyte Saga (1967 TV series)|the BBC's adaptation]] of [[John Galsworthy]]'s ''[[The Forsyte Saga]]'' on BBC2.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/f4d1222e5d5349ba937e75d6348dffd7|title=The Forsyte Saga: Part 1: A Family Festival – BBC Two England – 7 January 1967 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=21 November 2018}}</ref> The series concludes on 1 July.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/5ee75e9b977344d1aeabeb3afe0bdd96|title=The Forsyte Saga: Part 26: Swan Song – BBC Two England – 1 July 1967 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=21 November 2018}}</ref> **1 July – [[BBC Two|BBC2]] becomes Europe's first colour TV broadcaster. The colour service is launched with live coverage from the [[Wimbledon Championships]]. **23 October – BBC2 broadcasts the BBC's first bulletin of ''[[Service Information]]''. **2 December – Colour television is officially launched on [[BBC Two|BBC2]].
*'''1968''' **No events.
*'''1969''' **24 March – Debut of the surreal comedy sketch show ''[[Q... (TV series)|Q]]'', written by [[Spike Milligan]] and [[Neil Shand]], and starring Milligan.
==1970s== *'''1970''' **No events
*'''1971''' **17 February – [[BBC Two|BBC2]] airs ''[[Elizabeth R]]'', a drama serial of six 85-minute plays starring [[Glenda Jackson]] in the title role.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/188c4d5c9d0c4c4397b5e027010700c4|title=Elizabeth R: The Lion's Cub – BBC Two England – 17 February 1971 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=13 November 2018}}</ref> **21 September – ''The [[Old Grey Whistle Test]]'' premieres on [[BBC Two|BBC2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/73d16dcdba4e44b7abebfb96d1ec667b|title=The Old Grey Whistle Test – BBC Two England – 21 September 1971 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=13 November 2018}}</ref>
*'''1972''' **No events
*'''1973''' **No events.
*'''1974''' **22 February – BBC2 airs the drama ''Girl'' as part of its ''[[Second City Firsts]]'' anthology series.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/751cd5db682b4fc8a8221ae9cf32423d|title=Second City Firsts – BBC Two England – 22 February 1974 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref> The drama, which tells the story of an affair between two army officers, is the first on British television to feature a gay kiss, between two women.<ref>{{cite news|first=Hannah |last=Ellis-Petersen |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/jun/16/bbc-stream-1974-show-girl-alison-steadman-first-lesbian-kiss-uk-television-pride |title=BBC to stream 1974 show with first lesbian kiss on UK television |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=16 June 2016 |accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref> **5 December – Party Political Broadcast, the final episode of Monty Python's Flying Circus, is broadcast on BBC2.
*'''1975''' **22 January – 26 February – Drama series ''[[The Love School]]'', about the [[Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood]] is shown on BBC2. **19 September – The comedy series ''[[Fawlty Towers]]'' debuts on [[BBC Two|BBC2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/c0b8e1657e4c494f85d047983835c646|title=Fawlty Towers – BBC Two England – 19 September 1975 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=13 November 2018}}</ref>
*'''1976''' **No events.
*'''1977''' **No events.
*'''1978''' **6 April – The four-part drama series ''[[Law & Order (UK TV series)|Law & Order]]'' begins airing on [[BBC Two|BBC2]]. Each of the four stories within the series is told from a different perspective, including that of the Detective, the Villain, the Brief and the Prisoner. The series proves to be highly controversial upon its release due to its depiction of a corrupt British [[Police|law enforcement]] and [[legal system]].<ref>Newman, G.F. Television interview with [[Mark Lawson]]. ''[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00czhy9 Mark Lawson Talks to... G.F. Newman]''. United Kingdom: BBC Four. Accessed 3 April 2018</ref> **13 July – The original series of ''[[Top Gear (1977 TV series)|Top Gear]]'' begins airing on [[BBC Two|BBC2]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/53d7caaca2db42e9af4b102cb6bb061b|title=Top Gear – BBC Two England – 13 July 1978 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=13 November 2018}}</ref> having started as a locally produced programme at [[BBC Pebble Mill]] the previous year.
*'''1979''' **2 January – BBC2 broadcasts the first in [[Michael Wood (historian)|Michael Wood]]'s groundbreaking history documentary series, ''[[In Search of the Dark Ages]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/3e23b67ea70544e09405bdc6f78b3595|title=In Search of Offa – BBC Two England – 2 January 1979 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=13 November 2018}}</ref> **June – [[BBC Two|BBC2]] launches the world's first computer-generated ident, the [[BBC Two 'Computer Generated 2' ident|BBC Two 'Computer Generated 2']].<ref>{{cite book|title=BBC Channels (UK)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CStnLhkdwgIC&pg=PA17|publisher=PediaPress|pages=17–|id=GGKEY:U1P60JYBSLP}}</ref> **25 October – The final episode of the comedy series ''[[Fawlty Towers]]'' is broadcast on [[BBC Two|BBC2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/4fb5aa1d20a64f0b9a1d036080455133|title=Fawlty Towers Special – BBC Two England – 25 October 1979 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=13 November 2018}}</ref>
==1980s== *'''1980''' **28 January – The first edition of ''[[Newsnight]]'' is broadcast on [[BBC Two|BBC2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/86fbfed2b3b747d09dbb3826dd903bf5|title=Newsnight – BBC Two England – 28 January 1980 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=26 October 2018}}</ref> Its launch had been delayed for four months by the [[Association of Broadcasting Staff]], at the time the main BBC trade union.<ref name="Billen">Andrew Billen [http://www.newstatesman.com/node/136822 "Flagship sails on"], ''New Statesman'', 7 February 2000</ref> **25 February – The first episode of the popular political sitcom ''[[Yes Minister]]'', "[[Open Government (Yes Minister)|Open Government]]", is broadcast by [[BBC Two|BBC2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/91c4ae1a28b14c9bb86ed64e2872356c |title=Yes Minister – BBC Two England – 25 February 1980 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **March – The very first in-vision [[Ceefax]] transmissions are broadcast. These consist of 30-minute transmissions, which BBC2 broadcasts on weekdays between 1000 and 1030 and between 1530 and 1600. **[[BBC2]] launches its computer generated clock.
*'''1981''' **5 January – ''[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (TV series)|The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]]'', the television version of [[Douglas Adams]]' [[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy|radio comedy of the same name]] debuts on [[BBC Two|BBC2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/d4c03b911185453dabdcc22e73bfc7d8|title=The Hitch-Hiker's Guide to the Galaxy – BBC Two England – 5 January 1981 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=26 October 2018}}</ref> **20 January – [[BBC Two|BBC2]] airs live coverage of the [[First inauguration of Ronald Reagan|inauguration]] of [[Ronald Reagan]] as the 40th [[President of the United States]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/6dda0f6ea5ef46a6b22b9a8063e1cbe3 |title=The President's Inauguration – BBC Two England – 20 January 1981 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> **17 May – ''[[Grandstand (TV series)|Sunday Grandstand]]'' launches. It broadcasts during the summer months on [[BBC Two]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1981-05-17|title=BBC Two England – 17 May 1981 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 November 2018}}</ref>
*'''1982''' **10 October – ''[[Boys from the Blackstuff]]'' premieres on [[BBC Two|BBC2]] (last episode was shown on 7 November). **9 November – The first edition of anarchic sitcom ''[[The Young Ones (TV series)|The Young Ones]]'' starring [[Rik Mayall]] is transmitted on [[BBC2]]. **23 December – [[Service Information]] is broadcast on [[BBC Two|BBC2]] for the final time.
*'''1983''' **2 May – From today [[Ceefax]] pages are broadcast during all daytime downtime although BBC2 continues to fully close down for four hours after ''[[Play School (UK TV series)|Play School]]''. **27–28 August – BBC2 ''Rocks Around the Clock'' by broadcasting non-stop music programmes all day and also all night.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1983-08-27|title=BBC Two England – 27 August 1983 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=13 November 2018}}</ref> **16 September – BBC2 closes down during the day for the final time – all future daytime downtime is filled by ''Pages from Ceefax''. **19 September – ''[[Daytime on Two]]'' launches on BBC2. Broadcasting during termtime from just after 9am until 3pm, the strand encompasses the [[BBC Schools]] programming previously shown on BBC1 and the BBC's adult educational programmes which are shown at lunchtime. A special version of the [[BBC Two 'Computer Generated 2' ident]] is launched to introduce the programmes.
*'''1984''' **28–29 July – BBC2 hosts ''Jazz on a Summer's Day'', a weekend a programmes devoted to jazz music.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1984-07-28|title=BBC Two England – 28 July 1984 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=13 November 2018}}</ref> **25–26 August – For the second time, BBC2 goes ''Rock Around the Clock''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1984-08-25|title=BBC Two England – 25 August 1984 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=13 November 2018}}</ref> **23 September – British single TV drama play ''[[Threads]]'' premiered on [[BBC Two|BBC2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/41ce1c81c97940d89c024f28e885e07e |title=Threads – BBC Two England – 23 September 1984 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **5 October – BBC2 broadcasts an [[Open University]] programme at teatime for the final time. **8 October – BBC2 launches a full afternoon service, consisting primarily of repeats of [[Dallas (1978 TV series)|Dallas]] and old feature films.
*'''1985''' **7 January – The BBC ends its experiment with afternoon broadcasting and from this date Ceefax pages are shown continuously on BBC2 between 9am and 5.25pm apart from when ''[[Daytime on Two]]'' is in season and when sporting events are being shown. **11 January – [[BBC2]] debuts ''[[Victoria Wood as Seen on TV]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/a07403d12db54a89bc90921e91a21322 |title=Victoria Wood – as Seen on TV – BBC Two England – 11 January 1985 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **28 April – The World [[Snooker]] Championship Final between [[Dennis Taylor]] and [[Steve Davis]] draws [[BBC Two|BBC2]]'s highest ever rating of 18.5 million viewers. **27 July – BBC2 airs "Blues Night", an ''[[Arena (UK TV series)|Arena]]'' special dedicated to [[Blues|the Blues]], and featuring artists from the genre, including [[Sonny Boy Williamson II|Sonny Boy Williamson]], [[B. B. King]], [[Blind John Davis]], and [[Big Bill Broonzy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/5ba92d38c0aa4c449b64554d8153ae7a|title=Blues Night – BBC Two England – 27 July 1985 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> **30 July – Debut of the pop music culture series ''[[No Limits (BBC TV series)|No Limits]]'' on BBC2.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/2d1513aefd5148b98a9b19a507d71bc8 |title=No Limits – BBC Two England – 30 July 1985 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=2 January 2017}}</ref> **31 July – ''[[The War Game]]'', made for the [[BBC]]'s ''[[The Wednesday Play]]'' strand in [[1965 in television|1965]] but banned from broadcast at the time, is finally shown on television as part of BBC2's ''After the Bomb'' season.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/4493713?sid=21106160406853&uid=4&uid=3738032&uid=2 |title=The BBC, the State and Cold War Culture: The Case of Television's The War Game (1965) |publisher=Oxford University Press |work=English Historical Review vol. CXXI No. 494 |subscription=yes |year=2006}}</ref> **1 August – The nuclear war docudrama ''[[Threads]]'' is repeated on BBC2 as part of the ''After the Bomb'' series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbcone/london/1985-08-01 |title=BBC One London – 1 August 1985 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref>
*'''1986''' **30 March – [[BBC2]] airs the [[BBC Two 'Two' ident|TWO]] ident, which is used until 1991. **21 May – ''[[A Very Peculiar Practice]]'' debuts on BBC2.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/0fada2719813490d9c9a801e1a2e1ec2 |title=A Very Peculiar Practice: 1: A Very Long Way from Anywhere – BBC Two England – 21 May 1986 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **2 September – Ahead of the launch of all-day television on [[BBC1]], the weekly magazine programme for Asian women, ''[[Gharbar]]'', transfers back to [[BBC2]]. The programme moves to a new day and new slot – 9{{nbsp}}am on Tuesdays. **9 September – The last ever non-stop all-day [[BBC2]] [[Ceefax]] transmission takes place. **20–21 September – For the third and final time, BBC2 goes ''Rock Around the Clock''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1986-09-20|title=BBC Two England – 20 September 1986 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=13 November 2018}}</ref> **14 October – [[BBC2]] begins regular late afternoon programming by showing a film during the second half of the gap between the end of ''[[Daytime on Two]]'' and the start of the evening's programmes. **17 October – [[BBC2]] broadcasts a teatime news summary with subtitles for the last time. For the past three years this bulletin, which had been broadcast at around 5.25{{nbsp}}pm, had been the first programme of the day (apart from educational programmes and sports coverage). **27 October – The BBC launches its daytime television service and BBC2 provides a full afternoon service for the first time. However, when ''[[Daytime on Two]]'' was not being shown, BBC2 continues to broadcast ''Pages from Ceefax'' and does not start broadcasting until 2pm. It wasn't until 1989 that BBC2 started to show morning programmes when ''Daytime on Two'' was not on the air. **8 December – Six weeks after launching its daytime service, BBC TV starts broadcasting hourly [[BBC News Summary|news summaries]]. BBC2 broadcasts three early afternoon bulletins (at 2pm, 3pm and 3.50pm), the latter is followed by the mid-afternoon regional news summary which had been transferred from BBC1 on 27 October. Each bulletin is followed by a weather forecast.
*'''1987''' **22 June – The BBC's lunchtime children's programme moves from BBC1 to BBC2. It is shown slightly earlier, at 1.20pm. **30 September – BBC2 debuts [[Malcolm McKay]]'s screenplay ''The Interrogation of John'', a film concerning the police questioning of a potential murder suspect.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/94a406ce60e24c0b83a2a80df3b15d12 |title=ScreenPlay: The Interrogation of John – BBC Two England – 30 September 1987 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref> Starring [[Dennis Quilley]], [[Bill Paterson (actor)|Bill Paterson]] and [[Michael Fitzgerald (actor)|Michael Fitzgerald]], it later forms the first of a three-part series titled ''A Wanted Man'', which further develops the story and airs in 1989.<ref name="auto">{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/767e155addf647b2bf89aa0799a20ace |title=A Wanted Man – BBC Two England – 25 September 1989 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref> **31 December – BBC2 airs a five hour ''[[The Old Grey Whistle Test|Whistle Test]]'' special to welcome in 1988. The special, aired from 9.35pm on New Year's Eve to 2.55am on New Year's Day, takes a look back through the archives in what is the programme's final outing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/7531a047218742969d9af6d538ec2607 |title=87 Whistle Test 88 – BBC Two England – 31 December 1987 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> It will be three decades later in 2018 before a new edition of the programme is broadcast.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-43002005# |title=What's old, grey and making a comeback? |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=9 February 2018 |accessdate=9 February 2018}}</ref>
*'''1988''' **15 February – ''[[Red Dwarf]]'' makes its debut on [[BBC Two|BBC2]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/80e68eee3d7d4965b02ec5d443ef2fd4 |title=Red Dwarf: The End – BBC Two England – 15 February 1988 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=12 November 2016}}</ref> **25 March – BBC2 shows ''[[Two of Us (1987 film)|Two of Us]]'', a [[gay]]-themed television film.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1988-03-25#at-23.30|title=BBC Two England – 25 March 1988 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=8 November 2018}}</ref> It was produced as part of the BBC Schools SCENE series, and intended for young adults. It confronted the [[Thatcherite]] government's attempt to ban gay sex education in schools via the controversial (and since repealed) [[section 28]] legislation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gaycelluloid.com/search/088.htm|title=Two of Us gay drama|publisher=|accessdate=6 July 2016}}</ref> Given this backdrop, the BBC opted not to show it during the day and it was screened late at night on this day, even though it was originally created for a school audience. In 1990 the play was finally shown during the day, when it was broadcast in a lunchtime slot.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/search/0/20?q=Two+of+Us&svc=9371535#search|title=Search Results – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=8 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1990-02-02#at-12.15|title=BBC Two England – 2 February 1990 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=8 November 2018}}</ref> **9 May – The youth strand [[DEF II]] is launched on [[BBC Two|BBC2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1988-05-09 |title=BBC Two England – 9 May 1988 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> **11 June – The [[Nelson Mandela 70th Birthday Tribute]] concert is staged at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]], London,<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[African National Congress]] |first=Mike |last=Ketchum |url=http://www.anc.org.za/ancdocs/history/mandela/awards/wembley88.html |title=The Nelson Mandela 70th Birthday Tribute Concert, Wembley Stadium, London, 11 June 1988 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gcv6bC55?url=http://www.anc.org.za/ancdocs/history/mandela/awards/wembley88.html |archivedate=8 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=10 April 2009 |df= }}</ref> and broadcast to 67 countries and an audience of 600 million. In the UK it was broadcast on [[BBC Two|BBC 2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/a074950f7c2f4162b332f297e60c2e47 |title=The Nelson Mandela Birthday Concert – BBC Two England – 11 June 1988 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref>
*'''1989''' **16 January – ''[[The Late Show (BBC TV series)|The Late Show]]'', Britain's first daily television arts programme, which is presented by [[Sarah Dunant]] debuts on [[BBC Two|BBC 2]] directly after ''[[Newsnight]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/56ea7cc1148e4d9ca1e7043efce97522 |title=The Late Show – BBC Two England – 16 January 1989 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1989-01-16 |title=BBC Two England – 16 January 1989 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> **20 January – BBC2 airs live coverage of the [[Inauguration of George H. W. Bush|inauguration]] of [[George H. W. Bush|George Bush]] as the 41st [[President of the United States]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/5c5a2b24e36c4c9f9cf87f7d7dc7d82e |title=US Presidential Inauguration – BBC Two England – 20 January 1989 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> **2 March – First transmission of ''My Brother David'', an edition of the BBC2 schools series ''[[Scene (UK TV series)|Scene]]'' in which Simon Scarboro talks about the life of his brother, [[David Scarboro]], who originally played the ''[[EastEnders]]'' character [[Mark Fowler]], and who fell to his death from [[Beachy Head]] in 1988. The programme is repeated again on 19 June for a general audience as part of BBC2's ''[[DEF II]]'' strand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcastforschools.co.uk/site/Scene |title=Scene |publisher=BroadcastForSchools.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1989-03-02 |title=BBC Two England – 2 March 1989 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcastforschools.co.uk/site/Scene/My_Brother_David |title=Scene/My Brother David |publisher=BroadcastForSchools.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/331f43df873541ad958fb450795d2a34 |title=DEF II Scene – BBC Two England – 19 June 1989 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **21 April – BBC2's 25th anniversary. Prigramming includes an edition of ''[[Arena (UK TV series)|Arena]]'' in which the author [[Graham Greene]] sets out to trace a namesake who posed as him for many years, and an edition of ''[[The Late Show (UK TV programme)|The Late Show]]'' which looks at the early BBC2 jazz programme ''[[Jazz 625]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1989-04-21#at-23.15|title=BBC Two England – 21 April 1989 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> **19 June – For the first time, BBC2 broadcasts during the morning when not showing ''[[Daytime on Two]]''. Programmes begin at 10{{nbsp}}am, as opposed to lunchtime. **25 September – BBC2 airs ''The Interrogation of John'', [[Malcolm McKay]]'s 1987 screenplay, starring [[Dennis Quilley]], [[Bill Paterson (actor)|Bill Paterson]] and [[Michael Fitzgerald (actor)|Michael Fitzgerald]]. The film, about the police questioning of a murder suspect and first shown in 1987, now forms the first of a three-part series titled ''A Wanted Man'', which further develops the story. The second part of the trilogy, ''The Secret'', airs on 27 September, while ''Shoreland'' concludes the series on 28 September.<ref name="auto"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/0b3bf395d35741758312464f22136277 |title=A Wanted Man – BBC Two England – 27 September 1989 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/a1efeec1e24c4a58ae682959b4c5673d |title=A Wanted Man – BBC Two England – 28 September 1989 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref> **4 October – [[Jeremy Paxman]] makes his first appearance as presenter of [[BBC Two|BBC2]]'s ''[[Newsnight]]''. **22 November – [[The Stone Roses]] are invited to appear on BBC2's ''[[The Late Show (BBC TV series)|The Late Show]]''. During their performance the electricity is cut off by noise limiting circuitry, prompting singer [[Ian Brown]] to shout "Amateurs, amateurs" as presenter [[Tracey MacLeod]] tries to link into the next item.
==1990s== *'''1990''' **13 February – The US science fiction series ''[[Quantum Leap (TV series)|Quantum Leap]]'' makes its British television debut on [[BBC Two|BBC2]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/0d39b86a7c8349219b81d5dc65f955bc |title=Quantum Leap – BBC Two England – 13 February 1990 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=11 October 2016}}</ref> **14 April – BBC2 begins showing the 91-part 1988 Indian serial, ''[[Mahabharat (1988 TV series)|Mahabharat]]'', a dramatisation of the epic poem the ''[[Mahabharata]]''. The programme is shown in Hindi with English subtitles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/200b6217a7ac433481282da81fc91d1f |title=Mahabharat – BBC Two England – 14 April 1990 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> **3 October – The [[BBC Radio 1]] comedy series ''[[The Mary Whitehouse Experience]]'' comes to television with a series on BBC2.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/98110115932b46e0913cfdb38cf3f588|title=The Mary Whitehouse Experience – BBC Two England – 3 October 1990 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=22 November 2018}}</ref> **23 October – [[David Lynch]]'s critically acclaimed serial drama ''[[Twin Peaks]]'' receives its British television debut at 9.00pm on [[BBC Two|BBC2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/f63934036eaa4bc695558232c1f4843b |title=Twin Peaks: 1 – BBC Two England – 23 October 1990 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> **30 October – Debut of ''The Sentence'', an eight-part BBC2 documentary series looking at life inside [[HM Prison Glen Parva|Glen Parva Young Offenders Institute]] near [[Leicester]], Europe's largest prison of its type. It is the first time a television crew has been given access to the prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/bd3b98a452e94d1eb359a3b93ed4e008 |title=The Sentence – BBC Two England – 30 October 1990 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> **7 December – BBC2 broadcasts ''Your Move'', a pioneering interactive show in which the home audience are invited to play chess against grandmaster [[Jonathan Speelman]] using telephone voting to select each move.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/f9a76690edde4ce1ba33d14b0576d845|title=* Your Move – BBC Two England – 7 December 1990 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=23 September 2018}}</ref>
*'''1991''' **14 January – American television sitcom ''[[The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air]]'' is broadcast in the United Kingdom for the first time, making its debut on BBC2 as part of the [[DEF II]] programming strand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/5b6d233bfee04eb0b0799e27e43ce845 |title=DEFII The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air – BBC Two England – 14 January 1991 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref> **18 January – BBC2 airs a special edition of ''[[Arena (UK TV series)|Arena]]'' in which playwright [[Arthur Miller]] meets [[African National Congress|ANC]] leader [[Nelson Mandela]].
