In the film Mandela talks for the first time about his life and experiences from a personal standpoint.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/af19b0dcf7d14b368f0751d7dc4ae611|title=Arena: Miller Meets Mandela – BBC Two England – 18 January 1991 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=25 November 2018}}</ref> **12 February – A year after the release of [[Nelson Mandela]] from prison, BBC2 airs an edition of its ''Assignment'' documentary strand in which journalist [[Donald Woods]] returns to South Africa to give his personal assessment of that country's future.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/8aea770e64be4325878cf963e8fabff6|title=Assignment – BBC Two England – 12 February 1991 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=25 November 2018}}</ref> **15 February – The [[BBC Two|BBC2]] 'TWO' ident is also seen for the final time after five years in use. **16 February – BBC1 and BBC2 receive new idents, both generated from [[laserdisc]] and featuring the BBC corporate logo introduced in 1986. BBC1 features a numeral '1' encased in a globe, and BBC2 features eleven idents based around a numeral '2'. **18 June – BBC2 airs the [[Episode 29 (Twin Peaks)|concluding episode]] of [[David Lynch]]'s offbeat drama, ''[[Twin Peaks]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/cbb10507438346e09ba01a73a195ec0a|title=Twin Peaks – BBC Two England – 18 June 1991 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=18 September 2018}}</ref> **20 June – An edition of BBC2's ''[[The Late Show (BBC TV series)|The Late Show]]'' is the final programme to be broadcast from the BBC's [[Lime Grove Studios]]. **30 July – Debut of Australian children's television series for pre-schoolers ''[[Johnson and Friends]]'' on [[BBC2]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/efcd6f4a19044052bceb0ef5bd9f0128 |title=Johnson and Friends – BBC Two England – 30 July 1991 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=7 April 2017}}</ref> **26 August – BBC2 airs a day of programmes paying tribute to the Lime Grove Studios, which includes a remake of the 1950s soap opera ''[[The Grove Family]]'' featuring actors from the present day.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1991-08-26 |title=BBC Two England – 26 August 1991 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=16 October 2016}}</ref> **17 September – Comedy series ''[[Bottom (TV series)|Bottom]]'' starring [[Rik Mayall]] and [[Adrian Edmondson]] debuts on [[BBC2]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/b06ca40fe42e4d3e82a9b6cdaf8225ac |title=Bottom: Smells – BBC Two England – 17 September 1991 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=20 March 2016}}</ref> **20 September – BBC2 begins a rerun of [[Gerry Anderson]]'s classic 1960s television series ''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/1a876cccb32843edab9d363fe5ff83ae |title=Thunderbirds: Trapped in the Sky – BBC Two England – 20 September 1991 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=20 March 2016}}</ref> The series proves to be popular, leading to a shortage of [[Tracy Island]] toys in stores during the run up to Christmas 1992, something that prompts the children's television series, ''[[Blue Peter]]'' to show viewers and their parents how to make their own Tracy Island model.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-16216131 |title=Blue Peter to be shown on CBBC before BBC One |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=16 December 2011 |accessdate=20 March 2016}}</ref> An instruction sheet produced by the programme receives more than 100,000 requests.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/proginfo/tv/wk42/feature_bpeter.shtml |work=BBC Press Office |title=50 facts about Blue Peter |publisher=BBC |date=October 2008 |accessdate=20 March 2016}}</ref> **21 December – BBC2 airs ''A Perfect Christmas'', featuring the best of Christmas programming from the BBC archives. Shows include festive episodes of ''[[The Flower Pot Men]]'', ''[[Dr. Finlay's Casebook]]'', and the 1986 Christmas Day episodes of ''[[EastEnders]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1991-12-21 |title=BBC Two England – 21 December 1991 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **28 December – BBC2 shows the network television premiere of ''[[Hail! Hail! Rock 'n' Roll]]'', [[Taylor Hackford]]'s acclaimed documentary celebrating [[Chuck Berry]]'s 60th birthday, with footage of two concerts from 1986.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/cb8bdaaa35c146f094b9ceb9328ea0f2 |title=Hail! Hail! Rock n' Roll – BBC Two England – 28 December 1991 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref>
*'''1992''' **4 January – BBC2 airs ''Freddie Mercury: a Tribute'', a special programme introduced by [[Elton John]] and that celebrates the life and work of [[Freddie Mercury]], who died in 1991.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/4cf65e063c5c47668fe974c1454d306a|title=Freddie Mercury: a Tribute – BBC Two England – 4 January 1992 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> **21 January – [[BBC Select]] launches overnight on BBC1 and BBC2 as a [[Pay television|subscription service]] showing specialist programmes for professionals including businessmen, lawyers, teachers and nurses. The service ends in 1995. **20 April – ''[[The Freddie Mercury Tribute Concert|The Freddie Mercury Tribute Concert for AIDS Awareness]]'', an open-air concert in tribute to the late [[Freddie Mercury]] is held at [[London]]'s [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]]. The concert is broadcast on [[BBC Two|BBC2]] in the UK and televised worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/3de1ffa36fb646aaa8155c0d9c0ee33c |title=The Freddie Mercury Tribute – BBC Two England – 20 April 1992 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/6af87519ef624c5592691fa626949ed7|title=The Freddie Mercury Tribute Concert – BBC Radio 1 England – 20 April 1992 |work=BBC Genome|publisher=BBC|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **31 August – [[BBC Two|BBC2]] spends the evening in [[TV Hell]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/3434675fe7074666a8db53f1ebfb2524 |title=TV Hell – BBC Two England – 31 August 1992 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **8 October – BBC2 airs the first edition of ''[[Later... with Jools Holland]]''. Artists and groups featuring on this edition are [[The Neville Brothers]], [[The Christians (band)|The Christians]], Nu Colours and [[D'Influence]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/57a7ea9fa7404523b61b560b274694cc |title=The Late Show: Later – BBC Two England – 8 October 1992 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=11 October 2016}}</ref> **12 November – The first episode of ''[[Absolutely Fabulous]]'', a sitcom written by and starring [[Jennifer Saunders]], airs on [[BBC2]]. The series also features [[Joanna Lumley]], [[Julia Sawalha]], [[Jane Horrocks]] and [[June Whitfield]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/5a818ccdd2094b60a1857f85e0ae748c|title=Absolutely Fabulous – BBC Two England – 12 November 1992 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=29 July 2018}}</ref> **28 December – As part of a theme night devoted to (rival) broadcaster [[Granada Television]], [[BBC Two|BBC2]] airs the first new edition of ''[[University Challenge]]'' in five years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/22b5077f38f4495ab64401e4d22df4a8 |title=Granadaland – BBC Two England – 28 December 1992 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> The programme returns for a full series two years later, presented by [[Jeremy Paxman]].<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/4e5275fd846d49cc82a3186c94d1b8ca |title=University Challenge – BBC Two England – 21 September 1994 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **30 December – BBC2 airs ''Unplugged – Eric Clapton'', in which [[Eric Clapton]] plays acoustic versions of some of his tracks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/5768dfb506f040268ade617c5370afd5 |title=Unplugged – Eric Clapton – BBC Two England – 30 December 1992 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref>
*'''1993''' **20 January – [[BBC Two|BBC2]] airs live coverage of the [[First inauguration of Bill Clinton|inauguration]] of [[Bill Clinton]] as the 42nd [[President of the United States]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/6170580fbe3340d7996ccefd523e4e24 |title=Inauguration of the President – BBC Two England – 20 January 1993 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> **15 February – [[BBC Two|BBC2]] airs [[Oprah Winfrey]]'s interview with singer [[Michael Jackson]].<ref name=Independent-1993-02-15>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/television-tabloid-tv-1473177.html |title=Tabloid TV |publisher=Independent Print Limited |newspaper=The Independent |date=15 February 1993 |accessdate=9 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/39abdadbdcf240f8b96db0e512798e5e |title=The Michael Jackson Interview – BBC Two England – 15 February 1993 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **4 April – [[CBBC|Children's BBC]] begin to repeat the children's drama series ''[[Grange Hill]]'' from its first series in 1978, on Sunday mornings on [[BBC Two|BBC2]], as part of the show's 15th anniversary celebrations. These repeats end in 1999 with series 16, Prior to the repeats, [[Rugrats]] begins showing on the same date.<ref name="auto2">{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1993-04-04 |title=BBC Two England – 4 April 1993 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref><ref name="auto3">{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1999-03-07 |title=BBC Two England – 7 March 1999 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **17 April – ''[[Arena]]'' presents a new 4 part series "Tales of Rock 'N' Roll" on [[BBC Two|BBC2]] looking at the story of 4 rock songs of how they came about and the history behind them and who and what they involved. Starting with Peggy Sue who was tracked down in ''[[Sacramento, California]]'' to be found running her own drain-clearing company Rapid Rooter and then to be taken back to ''[[Lubbock, Texas]]'' to recall how she knew ''[[Buddy Holly]]'' and how her marriage to drummer ''[[Jerry Allison]]'' turned out. ''[[Heartbreak Hotel]]'' where the song came to be written after the 2 songwriters discovered an article about a suicide in a hotel in ''[[Miami]]'' after reading about it in the Miami Herald. Walk On The Wild Side looks at all the characters that were involved in the song and how ''[[Lou Reed]]'' used to spend time at Andy Warhol's studio where they all did (Holly Woodlawn & Joe Dallesandro were the only ones still around to tell the tale) and [[Highway 61 Revisited]] which looked at Bob Dylan's roots and everything that was connected with ''[[U.S. Route 61]]''. The series ran for four weeks on Saturday nights on 17 April, 24 April, 1 May, and 8 May. **20 October – [[Kirsty Wark]] debuts as anchor on [[BBC Two|BBC2]]'s ''[[Newsnight]]''. **26 December – ''[[The Wrong Trousers]]'', the second short film starring [[Wallace and Gromit]], premieres on [[BBC Two|BBC2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/e4422f9b7cc44405ab6fa52d8f92b3b6|title=The Wrong Trousers – BBC Two England – 26 December 1993 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> **31 December – BBC2 airs the first ''[[Hootenanny (UK TV series)|Hootenanny]]'', an annual [[New Year's Eve]] music show hosted by [[Jools Holland]]. The show includes performances from [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], the [[Gipsy Kings]] and [[Sly and Robbie]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/b384c565baa24a9b9b7bcc0d27da48f6 |title=Jools Holland's Hootenanny – BBC Two England – 1 January 1994 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref>
*'''1994''' **2 January – [[BBC Two|BBC2]] begins a repeat run of the 1960s US [[television]] series ''[[The Fugitive (TV series)|The Fugitive]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/af16ce71418c4e15886b43904bd45b19 |title=The Fugitive – BBC Two England – 2 January 1994 |work=BBC Genome |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2 February 2016}}</ref> **10 January – The Welsh language soap opera ''[[Pobol y Cwm]]'' makes its debut in the rest of the UK when BBC2 begins airing episodes daily from Mondays to Thursdays.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1994-01-10 |title=BBC Two England – 10 January 1994 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=15 January 2016}}</ref> The series was, shown with English subtitles, aired on BBC2 for three months,<ref>{{cite journal |jstor=41555909 |title=Welsh soap: "Pobol Y Cwm" and Welsh national identity |first=Caroline |last=Lewis |work=Critical Survey |volume=7 |issue=2 |year=1995 |pages=152–157 |publisher=Berghahn Books |subscription=yes }}</ref> and on an experimental basis.<ref>{{cite news|last=McCrum |first=Kirstie |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/whats-on/film-news/40-pobol-y-cwm-facts-7916603 |title=40 Pobol y Cwm facts to mark 40 years of the S4C and BBC soap |publisher=Trinity Mirror |newspaper=The Western Mail |date=10 October 2014 |accessdate=15 January 2016}}</ref> **4 March – BBC2 shows the network television premiere of ''[[Laurel Avenue]]'', the acclaimed US miniseries that tells the story of an eventful weekend in the lives of an extended African American family living in St. Paul, Minnesota.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/4874af356d09403f9fc7b9aac38f7220 |title=Laurel Avenue – BBC Two England – 4 March 1994 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> The second part is aired on 6 March.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/58225a7e23bf4631a7ad689e35d757a7 |title=Laurel Avenue – BBC Two England – 6 March 1994 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **16 April – [[BBC Two|BBC2]] celebrates its 30th birthday (four days early) with an evening of programmes selected and introduced by former controller [[David Attenborough]]. Among them are episodes of ''[[Elizabeth R]]'' and ''The [[Barry Humphries]] Show'', a 1967 documentary about politics in [[India]] and a new episode of ''[[Call My Bluff (UK game show)|Call My Bluff]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1994-04-16 |title=BBC Two England – 16 April 1994 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **2 May – BBC2 airs ''[[Cry Freedom]]'', [[Richard Attenborough]]'s acclaimed film about South African journalist [[Donald Woods]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/e482320e3ee648b9b9b3a1b68a663b64 |title=Cry Freedom – BBC Two England – 2 May 1994 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **23 May – The BBC2 youth strand [[DEF II]] comes to an end after six years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1994-05-23 |title=BBC Two England – 23 May 1994 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> **27 August – BBC2 presents a night of programming dedicated to [[Associated Television|ATV]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/51db99c3abdf48b2820db939bae6f50c |title=ATV Night – BBC Two England – 27 August 1994 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> **17 September – BBC2 airs the first edition of ''[[Top of the Pops 2]]'', a programme showing footage from present day editions of ''[[Top of the Pops]]'', as well as material from the series' archive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/9f4a571d39b24ec49518d67420d1c702 |title=Saturday Week – BBC Two England – 17 September 1994 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=6 January 2017}}</ref> **19 September – The BBC launches a weekday lunchtime [[business]], [[personal finance]] and [[consumer]] news programme. Called ''[[Working Lunch]]'', the programme is broadcast on BBC2 for 42 weeks each year. **21 September – ''[[University Challenge]]'' returns to British TV, making its debut on BBC2 with [[Jeremy Paxman]] as host.<ref name="auto1"/> **18 November – Debut of ''The Trial'', a series of documentaries aired on BBC2,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/e166c8077d82431d9967459571043258 |title=The Trial – BBC Two England – 18 November 1994 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> which were filmed largely inside Scottish courts in 1993 and early 1994. Filming of the series is possible because [[Criminal Justice Act 1925]], the legislation banning photography in British courts does not apply in Scotland. **17 December – BBC2 begins a season of films starring [[Burt Lancaster]] following his death in October. The season opens with ''[[Elmer Gantry]]'', a 1960 film in which Lancaster stars alongside [[Jean Simmons]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/4921da17b8664e67b6b6840a7878243e |title=Burt Lancaster in Elmer Gantry – BBC Two England – 17 December 1994 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref>
*'''1995''' **29 January – Start of BBC2's weekly roundup of proceedings in the [[O. J. Simpson murder case|O. J. Simpson murder trial]] with ''The Trial of O. J. Simpson''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/4e5b485df0134e2e8b2290e6c68ed86f |title=The Trial of OJ Simpson – BBC Two England – 29 January 1995 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> **15 February – As part of the ''Modern Times'' series BBC2 airs ''Death on Request'', a Dutch documentary showing a doctor giving a terminally-ill patient a lethal injection of drugs. The programme is criticised by groups opposed to euthanasia. **25 February – BBC2 airs a documentary about [[The Rev. W. Awdry]] called ''The Thomas the Tank Engine Man'' as part of their ''Bookmark'' series. The documentary is narrated by Hilary Fortnam, Awdry's daughter and includes a look at Thomas merchandise, the success of Thomas, images from the original [[The Railway Series|Railway Series]] books with stock narration by [[Sir John Gielgud]], interviews with several people such as The Reverend himself, fans of Thomas, Awdry's son [[Christopher Awdry|Christopher]], children's author and poet [[Michael Rosen]], various people who worked on the books and toys, [[Brian Sibley]] who also wrote the Reverend's autobiography, the people behind the television broadcasts and rights of Thomas in Japan and the producers of the television series [[Britt Allcroft]] and [[David Mitton]], plus a special behind the scenes peek of the 100th episode Thomas and the Special Letter and the Reverend criticizing the [[Thomas and Friends (series 3)|series 3]] episode Henry's Forest. **29 June – Debut of ''[[Gaytime TV]]'' on [[BBC Two|BBC 2]], the BBC's first gay magazine programme.<ref name="Independent-1995-06-20">{{cite news|first=Paul |last=Burston |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/gay-tv-as-in-lively-bright-playful-merry-1587377.html |title=Gay TV: as in lively, bright, playful, merry |publisher=Independent Print Limited |newspaper=The Independent |date=20 June 1995 |accessdate=4 April 2014}}</ref> **8 October – BBC2 airs the final edition of ''The Trial of O. J. Simpson'' as coverage of the trial draws to a conclusion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/d85f6dae6fc14c5b94671d0411b45c73 |title=The Trial of OJ Simpson – BBC Two England – 8 October 1995 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> **12 November – BBC2 airs ''[[Twin Peaks: Fire Walk with Me]]'', [[David Lynch]]'s 1992 prequel to the acclaimed television series ''[[Twin Peaks]]''. The film stars [[Sheryl Lee]], [[Ray Wise]] and [[Kyle MacLachlan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/f31512591c2b42b2942d6e9be86857a4|title=Twin Peaks: Fire Walk with Me – BBC Two England – 12 November 1995 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=18 September 2018}}</ref> **24 December — ''[[A Close Shave]]'', the third short film starring [[Wallace and Gromit]], premieres on [[BBC2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/824a87d685ef42fcbc3d1c86eb22ba00|title=Wallace and Gromit in A Close Shave – BBC Two England – 24 December 1995 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=13 November 2018}}</ref>
*'''1996''' **15 January–11 March – ''[[Our Friends in the North]]'', a nine-part serial spanning the 1960s to the 1990s in the lives of four friends, is shown on [[BBC Two|BBC2]]. **19 July–4 August – The BBC provides full live coverage of the [[1996 Olympic Games]]. Live coverage runs for 15 hours a day (1.40pm until 4.30am) with highlights at breakfast time and morning-long extended highlights of the previous day's action.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbcone/london/1996-07-22 |title=BBC1 listings 22 July 1996 |publisher=BBC Genome Project |date= |accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref> In addition to BBC1's coverage, for the first time, the BBC provides alternative live action during the overnight hours on BBC2.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/1996-07-26 |title=BBC2 listings 26 July 1996 |publisher=BBC Genome Project |date= |accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref>
*'''1997''' **14 January – Viewing figures released for 1996 indicate [[BBC One|BBC1]] and [[BBC Two|BBC2]] as the only terrestrial channels to increase their audience share during the year.<ref>{{cite news|first=Marianne |last=Macdonald |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/bbc-triumphant-in-ratings-battle-1283216.html |title=BBC triumphant in ratings battle |publisher=Independent Print Limited |newspaper=The Independent |date=15 January 1997 |accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref> **31 March – Children's television series ''[[Teletubbies]]'' premieres on BBC2.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/dcd1d7b7c7ec4f91866ca3876d85e221 |title=Teletubbies: Ned's Bicycle – BBC Two England – 31 March 1997 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=12 November 2016}}</ref> **10 June – BBC2 airs the television documentary ''Homeground: An Exile's Return'', telling the story of [[Martin McGartland]], a former British agent who infiltrated the [[Provisional Irish Republican Army]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/3900239cfec14e6bb1ceefe2fb365329 |title=Home Ground – BBC Two England – 10 June 1997 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=24 September 2016}}</ref> **10 September – BBC Two begins airing the six-part documentary series ''[[The Nazis: A Warning from History]]'' which examines the rise and fall of the [[Nazi Party]] in Germany.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/eeb031b868fc4723800fc9db6012cb64|title=The Nazis – a Warning from History: Helped into Power – BBC Two England – 10 September 1997 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=4 November 2018}}</ref> The final part is aired on 15 October.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/528210d024714d1a97d1535fbf76f208|title=The Nazis – a Warning from History: Fighting to the End – BBC Two England – 15 October 1997 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=4 November 2018}}</ref> **4 October – To coincide with the introduction of the network's new corporate logo, the channel is now officially known as BBC Two rather than BBC2. **19 October – BBC Two shows [[Steven Spielberg]]'s 1993 Oscar-winning drama ''[[Schindler's List]]'', a film based on the novel ''[[Schindler's Ark]]'' by [[Thomas KeneaIly]]. The film is followed by an interview with Spielberg and a profile of [[Oskar Schindler]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/c4adb0646a3144c7967634db1846e020|title=Schindler's List – BBC One London – 19 October 1997 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=25 September 2018}}</ref>
*'''1998''' **20 February – Debut of ''[[Robot Wars (TV series)|Robot Wars]]'' on [[BBC Two]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/29f3db9f6e1b417eb7ef2e6193dc113d|title=Robot Wars – BBC Two England – 20 February 1998 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=13 November 2018}}</ref> **21 March – BBC Two airs [[Richard Eyre]]'s [[King Lear (1998 film)|film version]] of his [[Royal National Theatre]] production of ''[[King Lear]]'', starring [[Ian Holm]] in the eponymous role, as well as [[Barbara Flynn]], [[Amanda Redman]] and [[Victoria Hamilton]] as Lear's daughters.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/f93f1b3f99264e39bba0210f7f38f7d0|title=Performance: King Lear – BBC Two England – 21 March 1998 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 November 2018}}</ref> **7 June – To mark the tenth anniversary of the death of [[Russell Harty]], BBC Two airs ''You Are, Are You Not, Russell Harty?'', a documentary paying tribute to the chat show presenter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/2149f6a6560746ae97c41b4b00532910 |title=You Are, Are You Not, Russell Harty? – BBC Two England – 7 June 1998 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **12 August – [[BBC Two]] announce plans for an evening of programmes dedicated to the [[Helen Fielding]] novel ''[[Bridget Jones's Diary]]'' and issues raised in the book for later in the year.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/149915.stm |title=An evening with Bridget Jones |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=12 August 1998 |accessdate=9 June 2018}}</ref> **19 September – BBC Two airs a special [[Bee Gees]] edition of ''[[TOTP2]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/8fd10783c64d4921b56beb0c13088e93|title=TOTP2 – BBC Two England – 19 September 1998 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> **10 October – BBC Two airs ''Blue Peter Night'', a selection of programmes celebrating 40 years of the children's television series ''[[Blue Peter]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/190117.stm |title=Here's one the BBC made 40 years earlier |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=10 October 1998 |accessdate=15 April 2015}}</ref> **26 October – ''[[Ads Infinitum]]'' debuts on [[BBC Two]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/b75f26924e754c0c995c03f3f8d6cef9|title=Ads Infinitum – BBC Two England – 26 October 1998 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=23 September 2018}}</ref> **17 December – [[Jane Root]] is appointed Controller of BBC Two, becoming the first female head of a BBC channel. She will replace the outgoing incumbent, [[Mark Thompson (television executive)|Mark Thompson]] in January 1999.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/237070.stm |title=Two's company for Root |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=17 December 1998 |accessdate=12 April 2014}}</ref> **29 December – BBC Two airs a special edition of ''[[TOTP2]]'' dedicated to [[glam rock]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/ebb135405efc4a72a123937b6b0e9080|title=TOTP2 – BBC Two England – 29 December 1998 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
*'''1999''' **11 January – The [[black comedy]] show ''[[The League of Gentlemen]]'' debuts on BBC Two.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/local-news/locals-relive-comedy-capers-in-popular-912399 |title='Locals' relive comedy capers in popular village |publisher=Trinity Mirror |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |date=4 March 2009 |accessdate=14 May 2014}}</ref> Along with ''[[The Fast Show]]'' and ''[[Goodness Gracious Me (BBC)|Goodness Gracious Me]]'', it is credited with boosting international interest in British comedy series.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/292749.stm |title=BBC comedy in a different League |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=8 March 1999 |accessdate=14 May 2014}}</ref> **7 March – BBC Two airs the final episode of the 1993 series of ''[[Grange Hill]]'', concluding a Sunday morning rerun of the first 16 series of the school drama which began in April 1993.<ref name="auto2"/><ref name="auto3"/> **26 March – Debut of ''As the Crow Flies'', a seven-part BBC Two series in which [[Janet Street-Porter]] sets out to walk the 350 miles between the [[Edinburgh observatory|Edinburgh]] and [[Greenwich observatory|Greenwich]] observatories.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/34d622103b66461e9da1f0715f29d7b9 |title=As the Crow Flies – BBC Two England – 26 March 1999 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **29 April – ''[[The Planets (TV series)|The Planets]]'', an eight-part documentary series exploring the [[Solar System]], debuts on BBC Two.<ref name="Guardian-1999-04-19">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/1999/apr/19/tvandradio.television4 |title=Everyone's gone to the moon |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=19 April 1999 |accessdate=14 May 2014}}</ref> **24 July – ''Goodness Gracious Me Night'', an evening of programming dedicated to the Asian comedy sketch show ''[[Goodness Gracious Me (BBC)|Goodness Gracious Me]]'' airs on [[BBC Two]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/401948.stm |title=A night of Gracious comedy |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=23 July 1999 |accessdate=20 April 2014}}</ref> **27 August – The BBC names [[Gordon Brewer]] and [[Anne MacKenzie (journalist)|Anne Mackenzie]] as the presenters of ''[[Newsnight Scotland]]'', BBC Two's forthcoming ''[[Newsnight]]'' opt-out for Scottish viewers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/431782.stm |title=Leading names present Newsnight Scotland |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=27 August 1999 |accessdate=13 May 2014}}</ref> **6 September – The popular children's programme ''[[Tweenies]]'' makes its debut on BBC2 at 10:30am and again at 3:25pm on BBC1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/f8c3d44d59f84f0e9917a2e9bd614f63 |title=Tweenies – BBC Two England – 6 September 1999 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=25 July 2017}}</ref> **4 October – Launch of ''[[Newsnight Scotland]]'', the [[BBC Scotland]] [[opt-out]] of the main ''[[Newsnight]]'' programme on BBC Two.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/events/newsnight/463230.stm |title=Newsnight Scotland |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=4 October 1999 |accessdate=13 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Williams |first=Craig |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/newsnight/newsnight25/4206477.stm |title=Devolution and Newsnight Scotland |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=25 January 2005 |accessdate=13 May 2014}}</ref> **7 October – ''Gimme Some Truth'', a 56-minute documentary featuring unseen footage of [[John Lennon]] is set to be aired on British television. Work was recently completed on the project, but a deal to broadcast it is yet to be agreed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/467885.stm |title=Unseen Lennon on screen |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=7 October 1999 |accessdate=31 March 2014}}</ref> The film is ultimately shown on BBC Two on 13 February 2000.<ref name="auto4">{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/cf913a6e0cbc472d811695b97607d7e2|title=Gimme Some Truth – BBC Two England – 13 February 2000 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> **24 October – Debut of the BBC Two documentary series, ''Playing the Race Card'', which looks at the history of race and immigration in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/482565.stm |title=Looking back at race relations |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=24 October 1999 |accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref> **27 October – BBC Two airs the 150th edition of ''[[TOTP2]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/893cb7f8b2b1421d8d756433d07f51e2|title=TOTP2 – BBC Two England – 27 October 1999 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> **16 November – [[BBC Two]] begins rerunning episodes of ''[[Doctor Who]]'', beginning with the first episode of the 1970 adventure ''[[Spearhead from Space]]''.<ref name="BBC-1999-11-09">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/511431.stm |title=Repeat treat for Dr Who fans |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=9 November 1999 |accessdate=5 April 2014}}</ref> **8 December – BBC Two airs a special edition of ''[[TOTP2]]'' featuring performances by US country singer [[Shania Twain]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/0a889b74728445bca9997c85e11fb04a|title=TOTP2 – BBC Two England – 8 December 1999 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
==2000s== *'''2000''' **17 January – BBC Two begins a [[Gormenghast (TV serial)|four-part adaptation]] of ''[[Gormenghast (series)|Gormenghast]]'', [[Mervyn Peake]]'s series of fantasy novels.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/ac37281405204214a51f8914234f09fc |title=Gormenghast – BBC Two England – 17 January 2000 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> The series, starring [[Jonathan Rhys Meyers]] is launched with a massive publicity campaign, but is panned by critics, and loses 40% of its viewership by the third episode. Figures indicate that the first episode is watched by 4.2 million, a healthy audience for a BBC Two programme, but that by the third episode, aired on 31 January, this has fallen to 2.5 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2000/feb/05/bbc.uknews|title=How BBC made a crisis out of drama|first=Sarah|last=Hall|date=5 February 2000|publisher=Guardian Media Group|accessdate=23 September 2017|work=The Guardian}}</ref> **13 February – BBC Two airs ''Gimme Some Truth'', a documentary featuring footage of [[John Lennon]] as he recorded his 1971 album ''[[Imagine (John Lennon album)|Imagine]]''.<ref name="auto4"/> **22 July – The ten part popular culture series ''[[I Love the '70s (UK TV series)|I Love the '70s]]'' debuts on BBC Two, with ''I Love 1970''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/dceebb7270c843d684b0de5de1d93392 |title=I Love the Seventies – BBC Two England – 22 July 2000 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=7 July 2017}}</ref> With each edition dedicated to a different year of the decade, the series concludes on 23 September with ''I Love 1979''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/68fcc64cedcd4970bcf399a62e33f2bb |title=I Love the Seventies – BBC Two England – 23 September 2000 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=7 July 2017}}</ref> **14 August – The [[The Weakest Link (UK game show)|UK version]] of ''[[The Weakest Link]]'' begins on [[BBC Two]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Chiara |last=Rimella |first2=Charlie |last2=Cooper |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/bbc2-at-50-the-50-facts-you-might-not-know-9271496.html |title=BBC2 at 50: The 50 facts you might not know |publisher=Independent Print Limited |newspaper=The Independent |date=20 April 2014 |accessdate=16 May 2014}}</ref>
*'''2001''' **13 January – Debut of the ten part [[BBC Two]] series ''[[I Love the '80s (UK TV series)|I Love the '80s]]'', which examines the pop culture of the 1980s. The series debuts with ''I Love 1980'', and concludes on 24 March with ''I Love 1989''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/abc3eb444e6f4cffae9a521c735e957d |title=Love the Eighties – BBC Two England – 13 January 2001 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=7 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/3da8013ee01f49a997fdc1605d04ed57 |title=Love the Eighties – BBC Two England – 24 March 2001 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BCB |date= |accessdate=7 July 2017}}</ref> **20 January – [[BBC Two]] airs live coverage of the [[First inauguration of George W. Bush|inauguration]] of [[George W. Bush]] as the 43rd [[President of the United States]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/b3f7cfa4556542769e4d2124bc90d8ed |title=The Inauguration of the President of the United States – BBC Two England – 20 January 2001 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> **15 August – Unveiling its autumn schedule, the BBC announces that 10-part [[World War II]] drama, ''[[Band of Brothers (TV miniseries)|Band of Brothers]]'' will air on BBC Two, instead of BBC One as originally planned. The broadcaster says the decision to move the series is to allow "an uninterrupted 10-week run", and not because it was considered not to be mainstream enough.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/1492257.stm |work=BBC News |title=Spielberg epic loses prime slot |date=15 August 2001 |accessdate=16 March 2014}}</ref> **18 August – Debut of the ten part BBC Two series ''[[I Love the '90s (UK TV series)|I Love the '90s]]'', which examines the pop culture of the 1990s. The series begins with ''I Love 1990'', and concludes on 3 November with ''I Love 1999''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/85bda45871c048fea6755ec7b5127e89 |title=I Love the Nineties – BBC Two England – 18 August 2001 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=7 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/f101e097eb4e458cbe7a072f6b689f55 |title=Love the Nineties – BBC Two England – 3 November 2001 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=7 July 2017}}</ref> **26 September – BBC Two airs a special edition of ''[[TOTP2]]'' featuring a live concert from [[Elton John]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/a12015307e3d4c1d96a0e451e9a6bc66|title=TOTP2 – BBC Two England – 26 September 2001 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> **14 November – [[BBC Two]] announces that the current [[BBC Two '1991–2001' idents|1991 idents]] are to be axed and be replaced by a new set of four computer generated idents on 19 November 2001.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2001/nov/14/marketingandpr.bbc|title=BBC2 gives its on-screen logo a new look |publisher=|accessdate=23 April 2017}}</ref> **19 November – [[BBC Two]] introduces a new set of four computer generated [[television ident|idents]] at 7.00 am, replacing the previous set of over 20 (four of which dating back to 1991). [[ITV2]] rebrands on the same day.
*'''2002''' **2 March – [[BBC Knowledge]] ceases transmission in the early hours (the first BBC channel to permanently close) with [[BBC Four]] launching to replace it at 7.00 pm. The opening night is simulcast on [[BBC Two]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/1848919.stm |title=BBC's channel Four debuts |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=2 March 2002 |accessdate=17 May 2014}}</ref> **3 March – The acclaimed US spy drama ''[[24 (TV series)|24]]'', starring [[Kiefer Sutherland]] as agent [[Jack Bauer]] makes its British television debut on BBC Two.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a6379/24-gets-sunday-evening-slot.html#~oBTUKNQYgGOS37 |title="24" gets Sunday evening slot |publisher=Digital Spy |date=23 February 2002 |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref> **6 June – BBC Two begins showing ''The Hunt for Britain's Paedophiles'', a three part documentary series following investigations by [[Scotland Yard]]'s specialist [[Paedophile Unit]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/bff38bc896d949619f5d25dd470f3caa |title=The Hunt for Britain's Paedophiles – BBC Two England – 6 June 2002 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> The programme proves to be controversial, even before going on air, as it is reported that after spending two years shadowing investigators, many members of the production team required counselling to deal with their exposure to the things witnessed by the unit's detectives. Executive producer Bob Long defends the programme, saying he hopes it will lead to better policing of the crime.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/2027864.stm |title=UK | The hunt for Britain's paedophiles |publisher=BBC News |date=2002-06-06 |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> The series concludes on 20 June.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/66ff6c36988d48b5b34fb2a3427c03ce |title=The Hunt for Britain's Paedophiles – BBC Two England – 20 June 2002 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **20 October – BBC Two's motoring series ''[[Top Gear (1977 TV series)|Top Gear]]'' is relaunched with a brand [[Top Gear (current format)|new format]].
*'''2003''' **6 February – Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] appears on BBC Two's ''[[Newsnight]]'' with [[Jeremy Paxman]] and a live audience, where he is questioned about the [[Iraq crisis]]. Blair is also taken aback when Paxman asks him about his Christian faith, and whether he and US President [[George W. Bush]] have prayed together.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/newsnight/2732979.stm |title=Transcript of Blair's Iraq interview |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=6 February 2003 |accessdate=2 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-27225422 |work=BBC News |title=Paxman's most memorable Newsnight encounters |publisher=BBC |date=30 April 2014 |accessdate=2 May 2014}}</ref> **9 February – After a long delay, [[BBC Choice]] is replaced by [[BBC Three]]. The opening night is [[simulcast]] on [[BBC Two]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-26452235 |work=BBC News |title=BBC Three: From digital first to online only |publisher=BBC |date=5 March 2014 |accessdate=5 March 2014}}</ref> **5 April – BBC Two launches ''[[The Big Read]]'', a nationwide search for Britain's favourite book. The project is designed to encourage the nation to read, while people will be asked to vote for their favourite novel.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2003/03_march/14/big_read.shtml |work=BBC Press Office |title=The Big Read |publisher=BBC |date=14 March 2003 |accessdate=23 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2003/03_march/19/bbc2_springsum.shtml |work=BBC Press Office |title=BBC TWO Spring / Summer season 2003 |publisher=BBC |date=19 March 2003 |accessdate=23 May 2014}}</ref> **17 May – Following a public vote to find the UK's favourite book, the BBC's ''[[The Big Read]]'' reveals the top 100 in a special programme on BBC Two.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2003/04_april/16/big_read_top100.shtml |work=BBC Press Office |title=The Big Read top 100 |publisher=BBC |date=16 April 2003 |accessdate=23 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2003/05_may/17/big_read.shtml |work=BBC Press Office |title=The Big Read Top 100 |publisher=BBC |date=17 May 2003 |accessdate=23 May 2014}}</ref> **15 October – BBC Two airs the documentary ''When Michael Portillo Became a Single Mum'' in which former [[Secretary of State for Defence|Defence Secretary]] [[Michael Portillo]] assumes the mantle of [[Merseyside]] single mother Jenny Miner for a week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/06f6f778dffd4e3a8c43f9dd0488bd3f |title=When Michael Portillo Became a Single Mum – BBC Two England – 15 October 2003 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.offthetelly.co.uk/oldott/www.offthetelly.co.uk/indexd8dc.html?p=4585 |title=When Michael Portillo Became a Single Mum |publisher=Off The Telly |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **5 December – The third series of US spy drama ''[[24 (TV series)|24]]'' will not air on BBC Two after negotiations between [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] and the BBC ended without a deal being reached.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/3293845.stm |title=No third series of 24 on BBC Two |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=5 December 2003 |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref> **13 December – [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' trilogy wins the BBC's ''[[The Big Read]]'' after receiving 23% of the vote.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/3317081.stm |title=Rings triumphs in Big Read vote |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=14 December 2003 |accessdate=23 May 2014}}</ref>
*'''2004''' **29 March – [[BBC Two]] Controller [[Jane Root]] will leave her role to take up a position with the [[Discovery Network]] in the United States, it is reported.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/3580417.stm |title=BBC Two controller leaves for US |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=29 March 2004 |accessdate=13 April 2014}}</ref> **13 April – BBC Two airs the television debut of ''[[Hawking (2004 film)|Hawking]]'', a drama about the life and work of theoretical physicist [[Stephen Hawking|Professor Stephen Hawking]], and which stars [[Benedict Cumberbatch]] in the title role.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/45dc870e95cd43f0ba8e936c12fc9534|title=Hawking – BBC Two England – 13 April 2004 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=23 October 2018}}</ref> **19 April – ''[[Tots TV]]'' begins screenings on [[CBeebies]] and [[BBC Two]], These broadcast continue until 2009 **20 April – [[BBC Two]] celebrates 40 years on air by broadcasting ''[[Happy Birthday BBC Two]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Oakes |first=Keily |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/3586571.stm |title=BBC Two's 40 years on air |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=20 April 2004 |accessdate=13 April 2014}}</ref> **14 May – [[BBC Four]] Controller [[Roly Keating]] is appointed to succeed [[Jane Root]] as Controller of [[BBC Two]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/3713571.stm |title=BBC Four chief moves to BBC Two |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=14 May 2004 |accessdate=13 April 2014}}</ref> **4 October – UK television debut of the US version of ''The Apprentice'' with [[Donald Trump]] on BBC Two.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/bdab99ad0e6247d79a5d4db51ff158ce |title=The Apprentice – BBC Two England – 4 October 2004 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **29 November – The BBC announces that ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' will move from its Friday evening BBC One slot to BBC Two, where it will air on Sunday evenings.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/4051231.stm |title=Top of the Pops leaves BBC One |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=29 November 2004 |accessdate=21 June 2014}}</ref> **2 December – BBC Two unveils its winter season of programming, which will include a major documentary, ''[[Auschwitz: The Nazis and the Final Solution|Auschwitz]]'', to coincide with [[Holocaust Memorial Day]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Jason |last=Deans |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2004/dec/02/broadcasting.bbc1 |title=BBC2 to commemorate Holocaust Memorial Day |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=2 December 2004 |accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref>
*'''2005''' **8 January – ''[[Jerry Springer: The Opera]]'' airs on [[BBC Two]], despite protests from [[Christian Voice (UK)|Christian Voice]] and other groups.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4154071.stm |title=Protests as BBC screens Springer |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=10 January 2005 |accessdate=1 June 2014}}</ref> **11 January – Debut of the six-part BBC Two documentary series ''[[Auschwitz: The Nazis and 'The Final Solution']]'' which tells the story of [[Auschwitz concentration camp]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/05ae7507d2c34e6d8dcc2d725a5b6962|title=Auschwitz: the Nazis & the "Final Solution" – BBC Two England – 11 January 2005 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=4 November 2018}}</ref> The final part is aired on 15 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/f309004e451046a3a46d61bc3ae9a92c|title=Auschwitz: the Nazis & the "Final Solution" – BBC Two England – 15 February 2005 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=4 November 2018}}</ref> **27 January – [[Holocaust Memorial Day (UK)|Holocaust Memorial Day]] and the 60th anniversary of the liberation of [[Auschwitz concentration camp]] are observed in the UK. BBC Two and BBC News 24 air ''Auschwitz Remembered'', a special news programme providing coverage of memorial events.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/4211499.stm |title=Pupils hear of Holocaust horrors |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=27 January 2005 |accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref> **16 February – The [[The Apprentice (UK series one)|first series]] of the [[The Apprentice (UK TV series)|UK version]] of ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. TV series)|The Apprentice]]'' debuts on BBC Two.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2005/02_february/08/apprentice.shtml |work=BBC Press Office |title=The Apprentice |publisher=BBC |date=10 February 2005 |accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/broadcasting/a19308/slow-ratings-start-for-the-apprentice.html |title=Slow ratings start for 'The Apprentice' <!--|accessdate=16 May 2007--> |publisher=Digital Spy |date=17 February 2005|accessdate=4 May 2014}}</ref> **19 March – Ahead of the return of ''[[Doctor Who]]'' to BBC television later in the month, BBC Two airs a "Doctor Who Night", with three programmes celebrating the series.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/bbctwo/england/2005-03-19|title=BBC Two England – 19 March 2005 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=25 November 2018}}</ref> **17 July – After forty-one years broadcasting on BBC One, music show ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' is switched to [[BBC Two]] due to declining audiences.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4646937.stm |title=TOTP announces Sunday move date |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=3 July 2005 |accessdate=21 June 2014}}</ref> This is not enough to save it, and it is axed the following year.<ref name="auto5">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/5099894.stm |title=BBC calls time on Top of the Pops |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=20 June 2006 |accessdate=21 June 2014}}</ref> **19 September – The most famous children's classic television character ''[[Muffin the Mule]]'' (who has disappeared from TV screens for a very long time) is back with a brand new 2D animated series on BBC Two. **26–27 September – ''[[No Direction Home]]'', [[Martin Scorsese]]'s documentary on [[Bob Dylan]], receives its broadcast premiere on [[BBC Two]] in the UK, under the ''[[Arena (UK TV series)|Arena]]'' banner.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/1bed5e4506504d5ba9f63174acd40f43 |title=Arena: No Direction Home – Bob Dylan – BBC Two England – 26 September 2005 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/0444a7de36e74da597d8656e07250754 |title=Arena: No Direction Home – Bob Dylan – BBC Two England – 27 September 2005 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref> **28 October – Sheffield based rock band [[Arctic Monkeys]] make their first appearance on BBC Two's ''[[Later...with Jools Holland]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/7dc970781ba64a79b523cf2e88ccacad |title=Later with Jools Holland – BBC Two England – 28 October 2005 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-13}}</ref> **21 December – The BBC is to trial a three-month experiment in which its Saturday morning schedules for BBC One and BBC Two will be swapped. The changes, taking effect from January 2006, are being implemented because of frequent scheduling changes caused by big events and breaking news stories, and will mean children's programming will be absent from BBC One's Saturday morning lineup for the first time since 1976.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4549160.stm |title=BBC mulls Saturday morning switch |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=21 December 2005 |accessdate=20 May 2014}}</ref>
*'''2006''' **20 June – The BBC announces that ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' will be axed, the final show airing on 30 July.<ref name="auto5"/> **30 July – ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' airs its final regular edition after being axed earlier in the year.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/5215906.stm |title=Curtain falls on Top of the Pops |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=26 July 2006 |accessdate=21 June 2014}}</ref> However, the show returns for a Christmas special.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6172060.stm |title=Piper and Lucas top BBC Christmas |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=22 November 2006 |accessdate=21 June 2014}}</ref> **31 October – Pop star [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] appears on ''[[Newsnight]]'', where she gives her first British television interview about her controversial adoption of an African baby.<ref>{{cite news|first=Jeevan |last=Vasagar |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2006/nov/01/musicnews.bbc |title=Madonna on BBC2 to defend adoption |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=1 November 2006 |accessdate=22 September 2018}}</ref> **17 November – [[List of QI episodes#Series D (2006)|Episode eight of Series D]] of ''[[QI (TV series)|QI]]'' is a [[Children in Need]] special with [[Alan Davies]], [[Rich Hall]], [[Jonathan Ross]] and [[Phil Jupitus]], who discuss the topic of Descendants with presenter [[Stephen Fry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/d7886b76ec004d5cac9c6fb6b4dce2e8|title=QI – BBC Two England – 17 November 2006 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=6 November 2018}}</ref>
*'''2007''' **28 January – BBC Two airs the final edition of ''[[Grandstand (TV series)|Sunday Grandstand]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/008e5a14e25544a1b74d674c6df31249|title=Sunday Grandstand – BBC Two England – 28 January 2007 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 November 2018}}</ref> **18 February – [[BBC Two]] launches 14 new idents designed by Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO and produced by Red Bee Media, with the "2" becoming a "Windows of the World" a portal through which the world is seen differently. **8 June – [[Adele|Adele Adkins]], a 19-year-old singer from London makes her television debut on BBC Two's ''[[Later... with Jools Holland]]'', performing her song "Daydreamer". She became one of the first artists to appear on the show without having released a record because producer Alison Howe booked her after hearing a demo tape. Adele's debut album, ''[[19 (Adele album)|19]]'', is released in January 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b007ng7w |work=BBC Two – |title=Later... with Jools Holland, Series 29, Episode 6 |publisher=BBC |date=8 June 2007 |accessdate=25 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/16df1c4bfc424ca4a93dbd6cbe0e9bed |title=Later with Jools Holland – BBC Two England – 8 June 2007 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Caroline |last=Sullivan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2007/nov/23/popandrock1 |title=Caroline Sullivan meets Adele |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=23 November 2007 |accessdate=25 April 2014}}</ref> **11 July – BBC Two debuts ''The Alastair Campbell Diaries'', a series in which [[Alastair Campbell|Campbell]] reads extracts from [[The Blair Years|his memoirs]] over footage of key moments in the recently ended [[Premiership of Tony Blair|Blair government]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/9639dcb8fe1f465e8cad9616cc06e992|title=The Alastair Campbell Diaries – BBC Two England – 11 July 2007 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref> The three part series is aired over three nights, concluding on 13 July.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/eeb58c215c26498bad9832d36eee75f5|title=The Alastair Campbell Diaries – BBC Two England – 12 July 2007 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref><ref name="bbc.co.uk"/> **17 October – The town of [[Whitehaven]] in Cumbria becomes the first place in the UK to lose their [[analog television|analogue television]] signals and start the [[UK digital transition|digital switchover]], starting with [[BBC Two]]. The other four channels are switched off on 14 November.
*'''2008''' **22 July – [[BBC Two]] Controller [[Roly Keating]] is appointed as the BBC's first director of archive content. He will take up the role in the autumn.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7519123.stm |title=New role for BBC Two controller |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=22 July 2008 |accessdate=13 April 2014}}</ref> **1 October – [[BBC Four]] Controller [[Janice Hadlow]] is appointed Controller of [[BBC Two]], replacing outgoing incumbent [[Roly Keating]] from November.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7646701.stm |title=Hadlow announced as BBC Two boss |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=1 October 2008 |accessdate=13 April 2014}}</ref> **5 November – BBC Two airs a ''[[Newsnight]]'' special on the [[United States Presidential election, 2008|election]] of [[Barack Obama]] in which presenter [[Jeremy Paxman]] famously addresses the rapper [[Dizzee Rascal]] as "Mr Rascal".<ref>{{cite news|first=Paul |last=Moody |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2008/nov/06/dizzee-rascal-jeremy-paxman-newsnight |title=Paul Moody: Jeremy Paxman should have shown Dizzee Rascal more respect |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=6 November 2008 |accessdate=10 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Eliot |last=Smith |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/nov/08/dizzee-rascal-paxman-jeremy-bbc |title=When Jeremy Paxman met Dizzee Rascal |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=8 November 2008 |accessdate=10 April 2015}}</ref> **19 November – ''[[QI]]'' broadcasts its last episode to be originally shown on [[BBC Two]], as part of [[Children in Need]]. The series moves to [[BBC One]] during Christmas.
*'''2009''' **7 February – [[BBC Two]] screens the first part of ''[[Iran and the West]]'', a landmark three-part documentary marking the 30th anniversary of the [[Iranian Revolution]].<ref name="IATW">{{cite news|url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2009/02_february/06/iran.shtml|title= Iran and the West: Saddam offered to "eliminate" Ayatollah|publisher= BBC Online|date= 6 February 2009|accessdate= 12 February 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090213083408/http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2009/02_february/06/iran.shtml| archivedate= 13 February 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> **7 April – [[BBC Two]] suffers its second worse peaktime viewing audience since 2001, with a share of 5.3%.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rogers|first=Jon|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/2009/04/bbc2_suffers_peaktime_collapse.html|title=BBC2 suffers peaktime collapse|publisher=''[[Broadcast (magazine)|Broadcast]]''|date=8 April 2009|accessdate=2009-04-11| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090414043340/http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/2009/04/bbc2_suffers_peaktime_collapse.html| archivedate= 14 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==2010s== *'''2010''' **23 June – Following the previous day's [[June 2010 United Kingdom Budget|emergency budget statement]], [[David Cameron]] and [[Nick Clegg]] are questioned by a live audience on its potential impact. The programme ''[[Britain's Economy: Cameron and Clegg Face the Audience]]'' is presented by [[Nick Robinson (journalist)|Nick Robinson]] and aired on the [[BBC News (channel)|BBC News Channel]] and [[BBC Two]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/nickrobinson/2010/06/cameron_and_cle.html|title= Cameron and Clegg face the audience|publisher= BBC|work= BBC News|first= Nick|last= Robinson|date= 23 June 2010|accessdate= 24 June 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100625044817/http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/nickrobinson/2010/06/cameron_and_cle.html| archivedate= 25 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
*'''2011''' **13 June – [[BBC Two]] airs the controversial documentary ''[[Terry Pratchett: Choosing to Die|Choosing to Die]]'', a film presented by [[Terry Pratchett]] which examines the topic of [[assisted suicide]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Gee |first=Catherine |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/8573428/Terry-Pratchett-Choosing-to-Die-BBC-Two-review.html |title=Terry Pratchett: Choosing to Die, BBC Two, review |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=13 June 2011 |accessdate=19 July 2014}}</ref> **6 October – [[Director-General of the BBC|BBC Director General]] [[Mark Thompson (television executive)|Mark Thompson]] announces that [[BBC HD]] will close to be replaced by a high definition simulcast of BBC Two. This ''BBC Two HD'' will work much the same way as [[BBC One HD]].<ref>{{cite news|title=BBC set to cut 2,000 jobs by 2017|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-15165926|accessdate= 4 January 2012|newspaper=BBC News|date=6 October 2011}}</ref> This move allows the corporation to save £2.1 million, used to count towards their budget deficit following the freezing of the license fee and the additional financial responsibility of addition services.<ref>{{cite news|title=BBC cuts at a glance|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-15186116|accessdate=4 January 2012|newspaper=BBC News|date=6 October 2011}}</ref>
*'''2012''' **18 January – A call by [[BBC Two]]'s ''[[Stargazing Live]]'' for amateur astronomers to locate possible [[extrasolar planet|exoplanet]]s, planets orbiting stars outside the [[Solar System]], leads to the discovery of a new [[Neptune]]-sized exoplanet by two viewers, one in [[Peterborough]]. The planet is named [[Threapleton Holmes B]] in their honour.<ref>{{cite news|last=Amos |first=Jonathan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-16612181 |publisher=BBC News |title=Stargazing viewer in planet coup |date=18 January 2012 |accessdate=19 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/space/9026837/Amateur-stargazers-discover-new-planet.html |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |title=Amateur stargazers discover new planet |date=20 January 2012 |accessdate=20 January 2012}}</ref> **12 March – [[BBC Two]] airs a programme in its ''[[This World (television programme)|This World]]'' strand concerning the Chinese television programme ''[[Interviews Before Execution]]'' in which [[death row]] inmates are interviewed by a reporter shortly before they are executed. Chinese authorities cancel the show following international interest generated by the documentary.<ref>{{cite news|first=Clifford |last=Coonan |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/dead-show-walking-chinas-death-row-interviews-series-faces-axe-7563279.html |title=Dead show walking: China's death row interviews series faces axe |newspaper=The Independent |publisher=Independent Print Ltd |date=14 March 2012 |accessdate=14 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Jones |first=James |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-17303746 |publisher=BBC News |title=China's death row TV hit: Interviews Before Execution |date=12 March 2012 |accessdate=14 March 2012}}</ref> **16 May – The [[BBC Trust]] confirms [[Children's BBC|children's programmes]] will no longer air on [[BBC One]] and [[BBC Two]] following the completion of the [[UK digital transition|digital switchover]]. Instead they will move to the dedicated [[CBBC]] and [[CBeebies]] channels.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-18083178 |publisher=BBC News |title=Children's shows to leave BBC One |date=16 May 2012 |accessdate=16 May 2012}}</ref> **19 May – [[Absent Friends (Dad's Army)|Absent Friends]], a fourth series episode of comedy ''[[Dad's Army]]'', is repeated on [[BBC Two]] for the first time since its original broadcast in 1970. Before this, the episode was left out of repeat runs because of the controversial appearance of the [[Irish Republican Army (1922-1969)|IRA]]. **9 August – The BBC commissions a one-off drama to celebrate the 50th anniversary of ''[[Doctor Who]]''. The film, ''[[An Adventure in Space and Time]]'' will tell the story of the team behind ''Doctor Who'''s creation and will air on [[BBC Two]] in 2013.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-19192040 |publisher=BBC News |title=Doctor Who drama to mark show's 50th birthday |date=9 August 2012 |accessdate=9 August 2012}}</ref> **23 October – After 32 years, ''Pages from Ceefax'' is shown for the last time during downtime on [[BBC Two]]. To mark the occasion the last broadcast is introduced by the symbol the channel was using 32 years earlier, older music is played and a final special image is shown thanking viewers for watching. The [[Plain English Campaign]] gives the service a lifetime achievement award for its "clarity" and use of "everyday words".<ref>{{cite news|last=Hand |first=John |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20032882 |publisher=BBC News |title=Ceefax service to end after 38 years on BBC |date=23 October 2012 |accessdate=23 October 2012}}</ref>
*'''2013''' **4 January – The [[CBeebies]] block on [[BBC Two]] airs for the last time. The pre-school programming would in future air exclusively on their dedicated channel. **26 March – [[BBC Two]] launches in [[High-definition television|high definition]] for the first time, two and a half years after [[BBC One]] did. **8 May – [[BBC Two]] Controller [[Janice Hadlow]] takes temporary control of [[BBC Four]] following the departure of [[Richard Klein (TV)|Richard Klein]] to become head of TIV factual programming.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/ariel/22455736 |work=BBC Ariel |title=Hadlow takes temporary charge of BBC Four |publisher=BBC |date=8 May 2013 |accessdate=13 April 2014}}</ref> **12 September – Debut of the period crime drama ''[[Peaky Blinders (TV series)|Peaky Blinders]]'' on BBC Two.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/proginfo/2013/37/Peaky-Blinders.html |title=Peaky Blinders |work=BBC Media Centre |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=17 November 2018}}</ref>
*'''2014''' **5 February – Debut of the dark comedy anthology series ''[[Inside No. 9]]'' on BBC Two.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kendall |first=Paul |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/tv-and-radio-reviews/10620378/Inside-No9-BBC-Two-review.html |title=Inside No9, BBC Two, review |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |newspaper=The Telegraph |date=5 February 2014 |accessdate=17 November 2018}}</ref> **6 February – The BBC announces ''[[Newsnight Scotland]]'' will end during 2014 and be replaced by ''[[Scotland 2016|Scotland 2014]]'' as part of a shake up of BBC Scotland's referendum coverage.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/13144328.Newsnight_Scotland_to_be_axed_ahead_of_referendum/ |title=Newsnight Scotland to be axed ahead of referendum |first=Phil |last=Miller |work=The Herald |date=6 February 2014 |accessdate=5 December 2015}}</ref> The final edition is broadcast on 22 May.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/schedules/p00fzl9b/2014/05/22 |title=BBC Two Scotland – Schedules, Thursday 22 May 2014 |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=18 November 2018}}</ref> **15 February – [[Janice Hadlow]] will step down as joint Controller of [[BBC Two]] and [[BBC Four]] to take up a new role in charge of "special projects and seasons" at the BBC.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-26139320 |work=BBC News |title=BBC Two controller Janice Hadlow gets new role |publisher=BBC |date=11 February 2014 |accessdate=13 April 2014}}</ref> **11 April – [[Kim Shillinglaw]] is named Controller of [[BBC Two]] and [[BBC Four]], replacing [[Janice Hadlow]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-26990256 |work=BBC News |title=Kim Shillinglaw named controller of BBC Two and Four |publisher=BBC |date=11 April 2014 |accessdate=13 April 2014}}</ref> **20 April – 50th anniversary of the launch of [[BBC Two]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Chiara |last=Rimella |first2=Charlie |last2=Cooper |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/bbc2-at-50-the-50-facts-you-might-not-know-9271496.html |title=BBC2 at 50: The 50 facts you might not know |publisher=Independent Print Limited |newspaper=The Independent |date=20 April 2014 |accessdate=25 April 2014}}</ref> **30 April – [[Jeremy Paxman]] announces he will leave ''[[Newsnight]]'' in June after 25 years with the programme.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-27230684 |work=BBC News |title=Jeremy Paxman to quit BBC Two's Newsnight |publisher=BBC |date=30 April 2014 |accessdate=30 April 2014}}</ref> **2 May – BBC Two's ''[[Newsnight]]'' appoints ''[[The Guardian]]'' newspaper's investigations editor, [[Nick Hopkins]] as its investigations correspondent.<ref>{{cite news|first=John |last=Reynolds |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/may/02/guardian-nick-hopkins-joins-newsnight-bbc2 |title=The Guardian's Nick Hopkins joins Newsnight |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=2 May 2014 |accessdate=7 January 2016}}</ref> **8 July – BBC Two brings back the "1991–2001" idents (based around a sans-serif '2') for the channel's 50th anniversary. Since then, the "1991–2001" idents have beyond their timeframe, meaning that they are now permanent and will air into 2015 and beyond. **4 August – The BBC broadcast a series of memorial events in Great Britain and Belgium marking 100 years since Britain's entry into the [[World War I|First World War]]. [[BBC Two]] broadcasts a memorial service at [[Westminster Abbey]], culminating at 11pm, the hour at which Britain's entry was confirmed.<ref>{{cite news|last=Simon |first=Jane |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-previews/world-war-one-remembered-bbc-3969648 |title=World War One Remembered: BBC runs a day of special programming to commemorate 100th anniversary |publisher=Trinity Mirror |newspaper=Daily Mirror |date=4 August 2014 |accessdate=5 August 2014}}</ref> **14 September – The closing ceremony of the [[2014 Invictus Games|inaugural]] [[Invictus Games]] takes place in London, with a music concert at Olympic Park featuring artists and groups such as [[Bryan Adams]], [[Ellie Goulding]], [[James Blunt]] and the [[Kaiser Chiefs]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Ringwood |first=Shaun |url=http://www.scunthorpetelegraph.co.uk/Invictus-Games-Closing-Concert-BBC-tonight/story-22920953-detail/story.html |title=The Invictus Games – Closing Concert on BBC Two tonight featuring Foo Fighters, Kaiser Chiefs, Ellie Goulding & Diversity |publisher=Local World |newspaper=Scunthorpe Telegraph |date=14 September 2014 |accessdate=15 September 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140917004505/http://www.scunthorpetelegraph.co.uk/Invictus-Games-Closing-Concert-BBC-tonight/story-22920953-detail/story.html |archivedate=17 September 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Paine |first=Andre= |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/music/invictus-games-closing-concert-queen-elizabeth-olympic-park--music-review-foo-fighters-frontman-dave-grohl-dedicated-my-hero-to-all-the-heroes-9732799.html |title=Invictus Games Closing Concert, Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park – music review: Foo Fighters singer Dave Grohl dedicated My Hero to 'all the heroes' |publisher= |newspaper=London Evening Standard |date=15 September 2014 |accessdate=15 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=McCormick |first=Neil |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/live-music-reviews/11095378/Invictus-Games-closing-concert-Olympic-Park-review-heroic-endeavour.html |title=Invictus Games closing concert, Olympic Park, review: 'heroic endeavour' |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=15 September 2014 |accessdate=15 September 2014}}</ref> **22 September – The BBC apologises after seven viewers complained about an edition of ''[[TOTP2]]'' that aired on 13 September on BBC Two which included a brief clip of [[Jimmy Savile]] from a 1971 edition of ''[[Top of the Pops]]''. The footage has since been edited out of the programme.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-29308337 |title=BBC apologises for airing Jimmy Savile appearance |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=22 September 2014 |accessdate=22 September 2014}}</ref> **1 October – BBC Two airs the ''[[This World (TV series)|This World]]'' documentary, ''Rwanda's Untold Story'', which questions official accounts of the 1994 [[Rwandan Genocide]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Gerard |last=O'Donovan |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/tv-and-radio-reviews/11133986/This-World-Rwandas-Untold-Story-BBC-Two-review-intense.html |title=This World: Rwanda's Untold Story, BBC Two, review – 'intense' |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=1 October 2014 |accessdate=1 March 2015}}</ref> **13 November – The BBC2 [[BBC Two 'Window on the World' idents|"Window on the World" ident package]] is seen for the final time after about 8 years in use. Although elements of it (programme slides) are retained. **27 December – Part One of the ''[[Top Gear Patagonia Special]]'' is aired on BBC Two and seen by an average audience of 4.7 million viewers.<ref>{{cite news|first=Liam |last=Martin |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a618578/top-gear-special-peaks-with-511-million-on-bbc-two.html#~p04q34F3OV17lk |title=Top Gear special peaks with 5.11 million on BBC Two |publisher= |work=Digital Spy |date=28 December 2014 |accessdate=31 December 2014}}</ref> The second part, which features the controversial Argentina leg of the programme's visit to South America, airs the following day and is watched by an average of 4.8 million viewers.<ref>{{cite news|first=Daisy |last=Wyatt |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/twitter-reacts-to-controversial-top-gear-patagonia-special-ending-9948007.html |title=Top Gear Patagonia Special: Twitter reacts to 'controversial' ending |publisher=Independent Print Limited |newspaper=The Independent |date=29 December 2014 |accessdate=31 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Jason |last=Deans |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/dec/29/top-gear-jeremy-clarkson-falklands-number-plate-tv-ratings |title=Top Gear Patagonia episode attracts nearly 5m viewers |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=29 December 2014 |accessdate=31 December 2014}}</ref>
*'''2015''' **21 January – The [[Wolf Hall (TV series)|television adaptation]] of [[Hilary Mantel]]'s novels ''[[Wolf Hall]]'' and ''[[Bring Up the Bodies]]'' debuts on [[BBC Two]] to much critical acclaim, but viewers quickly take to social media to complain about the poor lighting in the series.<ref>{{cite news|first=Jess |last=Denham |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/wolf-hall-lighting-sparks-twitter-complaints-while-others-praise-atmospheric-use-of-candles-9994883.html |title=Wolf Hall: Lighting sparks Twitter complaints while others praise atmospheric use of candles |publisher=Independent Print Limited |newspaper=The Independent |date=22 January 2015 |accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref> **3 February – ''[[Reinventing the Royals]]'', a BBC Two documentary pulled from the 4 January schedule because of concerns over the broadcasting rights of archive footage, is rescheduled for 19 February.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-31117713 |title=BBC Royal Family documentary set to be broadcast |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=3 February 2015 |accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref> **16 February – The BBC unveils a series of new arts programmes, which will air in primetime slots. They include a new BBC Two series titled ''Artsnight'' and a one off debate, ''Artists Question Time'', presented by [[Kirsty Wark]], which will air on BBC Four.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-31486069 |title=BBC unveils new arts shows as part of boost to content |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=16 February 2015 |accessdate=16 February 2015}}</ref> **4 March – BBC Two airs the ''[[Storyville (TV series)|Storyville]]'' documentary ''India's Daughter'' which includes an interview with the man convicted over the [[2012 Delhi gang rape]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-31744050 |work=BBC News|title=Indian media: Is banning Delhi rape film right? |publisher=BBC |date=5 March 2015 |accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> **17 March – The BBC confirms it has bought the rights to broadcast [[BT Sport]]'s ''[[The Clare Balding Show]]'', which will air on BBC Two.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-31929710 |work=BBC News |title=Clare Balding chat show heads to BBC Two |publisher=BBC |date=17 March 2015 |accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> The programme makes its BBC Two debut on 3 April.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32174352 |work=BBC Sport |title=The Clare Balding Show: Tom Daley demos new dive |publisher=BBC |date=3 April 2015 |accessdate=4 April 2015}}</ref> **9 May – Contemporary dancer Connor Scott wins the inaugural ''[[BBC Young Dancer]]'' competition, broadcast live on [[BBC Two]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-32680433 |title=BBC Young Dancer: Connor Scott named as first winner |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=9 May 2015 |accessdate=10 May 2015}}</ref> **17 May – BBC Two begins airing ''[[The Detectives (2015 TV series)|The Detectives]]'', a three-part documentary series following investigators at [[Greater Manchester Police]]'s sex crimes unit.
